meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Agakov, V.G.

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Physically homogeneous rotating spaces

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Fizicheski odnorodnye prostranstva s vrashcheniem

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Vestnik Moskovskogo Universiteta, Seriya 3. Fizika, Astronomiya; v. 20(4) p. 73-80; ISSN 0579-9392; Jul - Aug 1979; For English translation see the journal Moscow University Physics Bulletin (USA).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; RICCI TENSOR; ROTATION; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Metrics of all physically homogeneous nonstationary spaces with rotation have been found without using the Einstein equations. Obtained is a precise solution of the Einstein equations with energy-pulse tensor of an ideal medium for one of the metrics found. The cosmological model obtained is shown to be a nonstationary generalization of the Goedel model

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1979

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Kofinti, N.K. (Ghana Univ., Legon. Dept. of Mathematics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A spherical cavity in an Einstein universe

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: International Journal of Theoretical Physics; v. 19(3) p. 177-183; ISSN 0020-7748; Mar 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CAVITIES; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATTER; METRICS; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; RIEMANN SPACE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Suitable metric forms for the regions inside and outside a spherical cavity in an Einstein universe are derived by means of perturbation. It is shown that for low proper pressure, the cavity behaves like 'negative' Schwarzschild mass. Finally, the possibility of carrying over to the exact theory a proposed definition of the gravitational field in matter is examined. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

</descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Suitable metric forms for the regions inside and outside a spherical cavity in an Einstein universe are derived by means of perturbation. It is shown that for low proper pressure, the cavity behaves like 'negative' Schwarzschild mass. Finally, the possibility of carrying over to the exact theory a proposed definition of the gravitational field in matter is examined. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="GB">United Kingdom</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The eightfold way to color geometrodynamics

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: International Journal of Theoretical Physics; v. 19(3) p. 189-209; ISSN 0020-7748; Mar 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BAG MODEL; BARYONS; COLOR MODEL; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GLUONS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; MESONS; QUANTUM CHROMODYNAMICS; SOLITONS; SPACE-TIME; SPINOR FIELDS; STRONG INTERACTIONS; TORSION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; BOSONS; COMPOSITE MODELS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; HADRONS; INTERACTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUARK MODEL; QUASI PARTICLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Color models of strong interactions are generalized to a GL(8,C)sup(f) x GL(8,C)sup(c) gauge theory incorporating space-time curvature and Cartan's torsion. Following Salam, the dynamics is determined by an Einstein-Dirac-type Lagrangian. The resulting field equations are a nonlinear (due to the torsion) Heisenberg-Pauli-Weyl equation for the fundamental spinor fields and a generalized Einstein equation for the background metric of hadronic dimensions. According to this model baryonic quarks are confined in geon (black soliton)-type objects by the tensor gluons of strong gravity. This approach also leads to a black soliton mass formula which is in qualitative agreement with part of the baryon spectrum. Hadronic mesons are interpreted as gluon strings trapped in a multiconnected space-time. Interrelations of color geometrodynamics with other 'bag' models are pointed out. Finally, the conceptual origin of this space-time foundation of quark is presented. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The curvature collineation equations have been solved for the two families of Petrov type-N plane-fronted gravitational wave solutions of Einstein's vacuum field equations in general relativity. Both of these solutions always have non-trivial curvature collineations, i.e. vector fields xi with respect to which the components Rsub(ναβ)sup(μ) of the Riemann tensor for those solutions are Lie derivable. (author)

meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Gerlach, U.H.; Sengupta, U.K. (Department of Mathematics, Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio 43210)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Gauge-invariant coupled gravitational, acoustical, and electromagnetic modes on most general spherical space-times

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 22(6) p. 1300-1312; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Sep 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; COUPLING; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN-MAXWELL EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; PERTURBATION THEORY; SPACE-TIME; WAVE FORMS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The coupled Einstein-Maxwell system linearized away from an arbitrarily given spherically symmetric background space-time is reduced from its four-dimensional to a two-dimensional form expressed solely in terms of gauge-invariant geometrical perturbation objects. These objects, which besides the gravitational and electromagnetic, also include mass-energy degrees of freedom, are defined on the two-manifold spanned by the radial and time coordinates. For charged or uncharged arbitrary matter background the odd-parity perturbation equations for example, reduce to three second-order linear scalar equations driven by matter and charge inhomogeneities. These three equations describe the intercoupled gravitational, electromagnetic, and acoustic perturbational degrees of freedom. For a charged black hole in an asymptotically de Sitter space-time the gravitational and electromagnetic equations decouple into two inhomogeneous scalar wave equations

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Krechet, V.G. (Moskovskij Vechernij Metallurgicheskij Inst. (USSR))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Self-gravitating static massive vector field in GRT

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Samogravitiruyushchee staticheskoe massivnoe vektornoe pole v OTO

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika; v. 23(4) p. 56-59; ISSN 0021-3411; Apr 1980; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics Journal (USA).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; VECTOR FIELDS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Found is an exact static spherically symmetric solution for the combined set of the Einstein equations and massive vector Proca field in the presence of cosmological member Λ for the case Λμ2 (μ-1=hmc - Compton length of a vector particle) being the analogue of the Schwarzshield, Reissner-Nordstem and Fisher solutions. It is shown that considered equilibrium configuration of self-gravitating massive vector field forms closed inhomogeneous static cosmological model with the maximum radius r* approximatel 1/μ which mass M approximately 1056 g(at Λ approximately 10-56cm2) with respect of order of magnitude corresponds to the mass of Universe being observed It is also shown that with changing length scale a approximately 1041 times the cosmological model obtained shall have parameters of elementary particle with mass M approximately 10-26g and maximum radius r* approximately 10-13cm. The solution obtained and its modification due to changing the scale may be treated from the point of view of the latest hierarchical models of Universe in which elementary particles are the lowest stage of the hierarchical system while observed Universe-Metagalaxy is the next stage of the hierarchy

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

Zaved., Fiz</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0021-3411</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 23(4) p. 56-59.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1100" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="02277" assignment="indexer">cosmological models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="12768" assignment="indexer">fundamental constants</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11998" assignment="indexer">gravitational fields</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="10807" assignment="indexer">vector fields</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Found is an exact static spherically symmetric solution for the combined set of the Einstein equations and massive vector Proca field in the presence of cosmological member Λ for the case Λμ<sup>2</sup> (μ<sup>-1</sup>=hmc - Compton length of a vector particle) being the analogue of the Schwarzshield, Reissner-Nordstem and Fisher solutions. It is shown that considered equilibrium configuration of self-gravitating massive vector field forms closed inhomogeneous static cosmological model with the maximum radius r* approximatel 1/μ which mass M approximately 10<sup>56</sup> g(at Λ approximately 10<sup>-56</sup>cm<sup>2</sup>) with respect of order of magnitude corresponds to the mass of Universe being observed It is also shown that with changing length scale a approximately 10<sup>41</sup> times the cosmological model obtained shall have parameters of elementary particle with mass M approximately 10<sup>-26</sup>g and maximum radius r* approximately 10<sup>-13</sup>cm. The solution obtained and its modification due to changing the scale may be treated from the point of view of the latest hierarchical models of Universe in which elementary particles are the lowest stage of the hierarchical system while observed Universe-Metagalaxy is the next stage of the hierarchy</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="SU">USSR</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.content: Some exact inhomogeneous cosmologies with equation of state p=γμ

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; METRICS; SINGULARITY; UNIVERSE; VECTOR FIELDS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A new class of exact solutions of the Einstein field equations with perfect fluid source and equation of state p=γμ is presented. These solutions can be interpreted as spatially inhomogeneous cosmological models. It is shown that these models do not approach spatial homogeneity at large times or near the singularity

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Rosen, N. (Technion-Israel Inst. of Tech., Haifa. Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Bimetric general relativity and cosmology

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 12(7) p. 493-510; ISSN 0001-7701; Jul 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; DENSITY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEOMETRY; GRAVITATION; HELIUM; ISOTROPY; METRICS; SOLAR SYSTEM; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELEMENTS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; NONMETALS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RARE GASES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A modification of the general relativity theory is proposed (bimetric general relativity) in which, in addition to the usual metric tensor gsub(μupsilon) describing the space-time geometry and gravitation, there exists also a background metric tensor γsub(μupsilon). The latter describes the space-time of the universe if no matter were present and is taken to correspond to a space-time of constant curvature with positive spatial curvature (k = 1). Field equations are obtained, and these agree with the Einstein equations for systems that are small compared to the size of the universe, such as the solar system. Energy considerations lead to a generalized form of the De Donder condition. Simple isotropic closed models of the universe can be set up which first contract and then expand without going through a singular state. It is suggested that the maximum density of the universe was of the order of c5-h-1G-2 approximately 1093 g/cm3. The expansion from such a high-density state is similar to that from the singular state ('big bang') of the general relativity models. In the case of the dust-filled model the parameters can be fitted to present cosmological data. Using the radiation-filled model to describe the early history of the universe, the cosmic abundance of helium and other light elements can be accounted for in the same way as in ordinary general relativity. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.content: Some Einstein spaces and their global properties

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The global structure of a class of Einstein spaces is investigated. These spaces have algebraically special Weyl tensors and contain homogeneous hypersurfaces. It is found that they display simple examples of a variety of interesting configuration involving horizons and singularities. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Papadopoulos, D.; Witten, L. (Department of Physics, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, Ohio 45221)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Covariant boundary conditions in gravitational radiation theory: A new covariant definition of spatially asymptotically flat space-times

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 23(2) p. 267-271; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jan 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; RICCI TENSOR; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; RADIATIONS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is shown that the existence or absence of gravitational radiation from a spatially limited physical system can be determined and its magnitude calculated provided that the solution of Einstein's gravitational field equations obeys certain covariantly described boundary conditions. These boundary conditions are given on spacelike hypersurfaces, and space-times which satisfy them may be considered to be asymptotically flat

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Rosen, N. (Department of Physics, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: General relativity with a background metric

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Foundations of Physics; v. 10(9) p. 673-704; Oct 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; MACH PRINCIPLE; METRICS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; HYPOTHESIS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: An attempt is made to remove singularities arising in general relativity by modifying it so as to take into account the existence of a fundamental rest frame in the universe. This is done by introducing a background metric γ μv (in addition to gμv) describing a spacetime of constant curvature with positive spatial curvature. The additional terms in the field equations are negligible for the solar system but important for intense fields. Cosmological models are obtained without singular states but simulating the ''big bang.'' The field of a particle differs from the Schwarzschild field only very close to, and inside, the Schwarzschild sphere. The interior of this sphere is unphysical and impenetrable. A star undergoing gravitational collapse reaches a state in which it fills the Schwarzschild sphere with uiform density (and pressure) and has the geometry of a closed Einstein universe. Any charge present is on the surface of the sphere. Elementary particles may have similar structures

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.content: Brinkman's theorem in general relativity and non-Riemannian field theories

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 12(9) p. 767-773; ISSN 0001-7701; Sep 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CONFORMAL MAPPING; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN-SCHROEDINGER THEORY; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; METRICS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME; VISIBLE RADIATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; RADIATIONS; SPACE; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A theorem due to Brinkman states that, given a solution of the vacuum general relativistic field equations, it is never possible to generate a further solution by means of a nontrivial conformal transformation. It is pointed out here that there are exceptions to this result. The discussion is then extended to the nonsymmetric unified field theory, and the circumstances under which this theory admits a rigidly valid analog of Brinkman's theorem are investigated. (author)

meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Briggs, C.; Cohen, J.M.; DeWoolfson, G.L.; Kegeles, L.S. (Harvard Univ., Cambridge, MA)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Slowly rotating bodies with arbitrary charge in general relativity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 23(6) p. 1235-1243; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Mar 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; CHARGED PARTICLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN-MAXWELL EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GYROMAGNETIC RATIO; ROTATION; SPACE-TIME; TENSOR FORCES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The Einstein-Maxwell equations are solved for a slowly rotating body with arbitrary charge. The solution is applied to a thin, rotating, charged shell. The angular momentum, gyromagnetic ratio, and other quantities of physical interest are computed. In particular, whenever the charge is less than the mass (but not necessarily small) the gyromagnetic ratio approaches 2 as the shell radius approaches the horizon. Under these conditions the rotational velocity of the inertial frames inside the shell approaches the rotational velocity of the shell. When the charge is greater than the mass there is no horizon and the gyromagnetic ratio can exceed 2. Furthermore, an example is given in which the inertial frames within the shell rotate in a direction opposite that of the shell

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Denisov, V.I.; Logunov, A.A. (Moskovskij Gosudarstvennyj Univ. (USSR))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Does general relativity theory possess the classical newtonian limit

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Imeet li obshchaya teoriya otnositel'nosti klassicheskij n'yutonovskij predel

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Teoreticheskaya i Matematicheskaya Fizika; v. 45(3) p. 291-301; ISSN 0564-6162; Dec 1980; For English translation see the journal Theoretical and Mathematical Physics (USA).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CLASSICAL MECHANICS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; INTEGRALS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MECHANICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A detailed comparison of newtonian approximation of the Einstein theory and the Newton theory of gravity is made. A difference of principle between these two theories is clarified at the stage of obtaining integrals of motion. Exact eqautions of motion and Einstein equations shows the existence only zero integrals of motion as well as in the newtonian approximation. A conclusion is that GRT has no classical newtonian limit, since the integrals of motion in the Newton theory of gravity and in the newtonian approximation of the Einstein theory do not coincide

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Uravneniya dvizheniya chernoj dyry v kvazistatsionarnom priblizhenii

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika; (no.11) p. 21-26; ISSN 0021-3411; 1980; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics Journal (USA).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GEODESICS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MECHANICS; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Black hole motion is considered under the effect of external actions from the point of view of a remoted observer. The shift of the black hole and the metrix structure are found at the presence of other gravitational bodies using the Zerilli equation. It is shown that in the region, where the space curvature is small, the contribution of the field of the black hole, moving with acceleration, coincides in configuration with the field of usual body, black hole motion in quasistationary approximation occuring according to laws of Newtonian dynamics

meta.content: January 1980

meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; KERR METRIC; ROTATION; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DISTRIBUTION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Any stationary, asymptotically flat solution to Einstein's equation is shown to asymptotically approach the Kerr solution in a precise sense. As an application of this result a technical lemma on the existence of harmonic coordinates near infinity is proved. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.content: Exact spatially inhomogeneous cosmologies

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 14(5) p. 1131-1147; ISSN 0305-4470; May 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUID FLOW; INHOMOGENEOUS FIELDS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The aim of this paper is to give an overview of the derivation and properties of exact solutions of the Einstein field equations which are spatially inhomogeneous with the source assumed to be an irrotational perfect fluid. It is shown that the known such spatially inhomogeneous solutions either admit a group of isometries with 2D orbits or are algebraically special. The solutions are related to a previously given classification scheme which is based on the intrinsic and extrinsic geometry of the hypersurfaces orthogonal to the fluid flow. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Letelier, P.S.; Machado, R. (Departamento de Fisica, Universidade de Brasilia, 70 910 Brasilia, D.F., Brazil)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Self-graviting anisotropic fluids with plane symmetry

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ANISOTROPY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The general solution to Einstein's equations coupled to an anisotropic fluid described by two perfect-fluid components is obtained in the case that (1) the space--time is plane-symmetric, (2) each fluid component is irrotational, and (3) each one obeys the equation of state pressure = energy density. The method used consists of solving the equivalent problem of the Einstein's equations coupled to a complex massless-scalar field. The space-time singularities are studied using the concept of velocity-dominated singularity. Comoving systems of coordinates are also studied

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Improved standard cosmology

meta.content: United States

meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 23(10) p. 2137-2141; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 May 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GALAXY CLUSTERS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; SYMMETRY; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: An exact solution of Einstein's equations is given. It represents spherically symmetric clusters of galaxies, with inhomogeneous inverse-square density profiles, embedded in a homogeneous Einstein--de Sitter universe. This model represents an improved standard cosmology, in that it is in better agreement with the observation that most galaxies are in clusters than is the purely homogeneous Einstein--de Sitter model. The new model agrees with a recent reformulation of the cosmological principle

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MATHEMATICS; POINCARE GROUPS; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The zero set of a momentum mapping is shown to have a singularity at each point with symmetry. The zero set is diffeomorphic to the product of a manifold and the zero set of a homogeneous quadratic function. The proof uses the Kuranishi theory of deformations. Among the applications, it is shown that the set of all solutions of the Yang-Mills equations on a Lorentz manifold has a singularity at any solution with symmetry, in the sense of a pure gauge symmetry. Similarly, the set of solutions of Einstein's equations has a singularity at any solution that has spacelike Killing fields, provided the spacetime has a compact Cauchy surface. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Ko, M.; Ludvigsen, M.; Newman, E.T.; Tod, K.P. (Pittsburgh Univ., PA (USA). Dept. of Mathematics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The theory of H-space

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physics Reports; v. 71(2) p. 1-139; ISSN 0370-1573; May 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The theory of H-space, the four-dimensional manifold of those complex null hypersurfaces of an asymptotically flat space-time which are asymptotically shear-free, is reviewed. In addition to a discussion of the origins of the theory, we present two independent formalisms for the derivation of the basic properties of H-space: that it is endowed with a natural holomorphic complex Riemannian metric which satisfies the vacuum Einstein equations and whose Weyl tensor is self-dual. We show the connection of our work on H-space to that of Plebanski and to the theory of deformed twistor spaces, due to Penrose. Finally, there is a discussion of equations of motion in H-space. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A gravitational thin--sandwich conjecture was first proposed by Wheeler and coworkers during the period 1962--4. The present paper contains a proof of the nonglobal form of this gravitational thin--sandwich conjecture. The proof (a) applies for arbitrary choices of the spatial metric and its time derivative; and (b) demonstrates the existence on a spacelike three-surface of solutions which satisfy conditions of continuity known to be sufficient to obtain existence and uniqueness of solutions to Einstein's equations off the three-surface and existence and uniqueness of geodesics. Riquier's existence theorem plays an important role in the proof. The relationship of the present results to previous work is discussed. Some global questions associated with the thin--sandwich conjecture are clarified. Some aspects of the relationship of the thin--sandwich conjecture to the problem of the quantization of the gravitational field are noted. Both the vacuum case and the case of a nonviscous fluid are included. The discussion allows for an arbitrary equation of state p = p

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We apply the weak field approximation to the most general gravitational field equations in Poincare gauge theory. The weak gravitational field h sub(μν) is a multimass field obeying a fourth-order field equation. In the Newtonian approximation we show that there are two routes to arrive at the Newtonian potential. The torsion field is decomposed into six irreducibe building blocks with spin sup(parity), 2+, 2-, 1+, 1-, 0+ and 0-, each of which obeys the Klein-Gordon equation. Finally, we construct a possible candidate for the massless graviton field which obeys the linearized Einstein equation. (author)

meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In the class of homogeneous spaces the self-consistent system of Einstein-Vlasov equations is investigated. The anisotropic cosmological Bianki model of 1 type with killing orthogonal vectors is considered in detail. The tensor of energy-momentum of collisionless gas is spatiallly anisotropic. Exact solutions of Einstein-Vlasov equations in the case of strong anisotropy have been found. The behaviour of small disturbances for mixture of ideal liquid and collisionless gas as well as for non relativistic collisionless gas is investigated

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Christodoulou, D. (Max-Planck-Institut fuer Physik und Astrophysik, Garching (Germany, F.R.). Inst. fuer Astrophysik); O'Murchadha, N. (University Coll., Cork (Ireland). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The boost problem in general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Communications in Mathematical Physics; v. 80(2) p. 271-300; ISSN 0010-3616; Jul 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CAUCHY PROBLEM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONAL ANALYSIS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GLOBAL ANALYSIS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We show that any asymptotically flat initial data for the Einstein field equations have a development which includes complete spacelike surfaces boosted relative to the intial surface. Furthermore, the asymptotic fall off is preserved along these boosted surfaces and there exists a global system of harmonic coordinates on such a development. We also extend former results on global solutions of the constraint equations. By virtue of this extension, the constraint and evolution parts of the problem fit together exactly. Several theorems are given which concern the behaviour in the large of general classes of linear and quasilinear differential systems. This paper contains in addition a systematic exposition of the functional spaces employed. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A class of solutions of the Einstein-Cartan theory for the static spherical dust distribution is obtained. The equilibrium of the distribution is found to be due to the balance of the gravitational attraction and the repulsion due to the spin and torsion effect

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Carmeli, M. (Ben-Gurion Univ. of the Negev, Beersheba (Israel). Dept. of Physics); Charach, C. (Ben-Gurion Univ. of the Negev, Beersheba (Israel). Dept. of Physics; Wisconsin Univ., Milwaukee (USA). Dept. of Physics); Malin, S. (Ben-Gurion Univ. of the Negev, Beersheba (Israel). Dept. of Physics; Colgate Univ., Hamilton, NY (USA). Dept. of Physics and Astronomy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Survey of cosmological models with gravitational, scalar and electromagnetic waves

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physics Reports; v. 76(2) p. 79-156; ISSN 0370-1573; Oct 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1000)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; SCALARS; SYMMETRY BREAKING

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RADIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This paper gives an overview and reviews some recent investigations of anisotropic and inhomogeneous models. A class of models, which admit an Abelian two-parameter group of isometries, is considered in detail. Within this class of models we present exact solutions of the Einstein field equations. These solutions describe inhomogeneous cosmological models containing gravitational, scalar and electromagnetic waves. The solutions are used to study the effect of the symmetry breaking in corresponding Bianchi models. The nonlinear dynamics of primordial inhomogeneities is considered. The global evolution of the inhomogeneous models considered is also investigated. Finally we discuss the validity of various assumptions, used in the earlier treatments of inhomogeneous models. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Manoff, S. (Bylgarska Akademiya na Naukite, Sofia. Inst. za Yadrena Izsledvaniya i Yadrena Energetika)

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Equations for the gravitational field and local conserved quantities in the general theory of relativity

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; MATHEMATICS; TENSORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: By utilization of the method of Lagrangians with covariant derivatives (MLCD) the different energy-momentum tensors (canonical, generalized canonical, symmetrical) and the relations between them are considered. On this basis, Einstein's theory of gravitation is studied as a field theory with a Lagrangian density of the type Lsub(g)=√-g.Lsub(g)(gsub(ij),Rsub(A)), (Rsub(A)=Rsub(ijkl)). It is shown that the energy-momentum tensors of the gravitational field can be defined for this theory. The symmetrical energy-momentum tensor of the gravitational field sub(gs)Tsub(k)sup(i), which in the general case is not a local conserved quantity (sub(gs)Tsub(k)sup(i)sub(;i) unequal 0) (in contrast to the material fields satisfying condition sub(Ms)Tsub(k)sup(i)sub(;i) = 0), is equal to zero for the gravitational field in vacuum (cosmological constant Λ = 0). Equations of the gravitational field of a new type are suggested, leading to equations of motion (sub(Ms)Tsub(k)sup(i) + sub(gs)Tsub(k)sup(i))sub(;i) = 0. The equations corresponding to the Lagrangian density Lsub(g)=(√-g/kappasub(o)) (R - lambda approximately), lambda approximately = const., are considered. The equations of Einstein Rsub(ij) = 0 are obtained in the case of gravitational field in vacuum. Some particular cases are examined as an illustration to material fields and the corresponding gravitational equations. (author)

meta.content: January 1979

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A tentative purely geometrical machian framework for describing gravity and inertia

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 24(9) p. 297-305; ISSN 0024-1318; 3 Mar 1979; 17 refs.

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MACH PRINCIPLE; MOMENT OF INERTIA

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; HYPOTHESIS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The purely geometrical Machian approach to gravitation presented in this letter improves an already published one. In any non vacuum cosmos the gravitational equations in gravitational units are identical to Einstein's equations, while the equations describing the gravitational field in local atomic units are integrodifferential equations in agreement with the available experimental data. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1979

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: McKellar, R.J. (Department of Applied Mathematics, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ontario, Canada, N2L 3G1)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Uniqueness of gravity as a Poincare or Lorentz gauge theory

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; LORENTZ TRANSFORMATIONS; POINCARE GROUPS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The uniqueness of the Einstein--Cartan--Sciama--Kibble theory is examined using a concomitant approach. The demand that the Lagrangian be a scalar density under coordinate transformations and a scalar under Poincare or Lorentz gauge transformations as well as be degenerate in the order of the Euler--Lagrange expressions determines a class of Lagrangians whose Euler--Lagrange equations reduce essentially to the Einstein vacuum field equations with cosmological term

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Shikin, I.S. (Moskovskij Gosudarstvennyj Univ. (USSR). Nauchno-Issledovatel'skij Inst. Mekhaniki)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Investigation of self-similar gravitational fields in space-time with plane symmetry

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Issledovanie avtomodel'nykh polej tyagoteniya v prostranstve-vremeni s ploskoj simmetriej

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Zhurnal Ehksperimental'noj i Teoreticheskoj Fiziki; v. 81(3) p. 801-813; ISSN 0044-4510; Sep 1981; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics - JETP (USA).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CONFORMAL GROUPS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SHOCK WAVES; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In the framework of general relativity for matter with equation of state p=(γ-1)e gravitational fields with plane symmetry are considered which also admit a conformal group such that the metric depends on z=x1/x0 (self-similar solutions for space-times with plane symmetry). The Einstein equations are thus reduced to a system of ordinary differential equations and its investigation requires a qualitative analysis on two-dimensional phase plane. Some exact solutions are given. The t-region when a coordinate z is timelike and the s-region when z is spacelike are introduced. A special case of structure of the metric which contains plane Friedmann model is considered in detail. Construction of analytic solutions and solutions with weak and strong discontinuities (shock waves and contact discontinuities) is discussed. Solutions are considered which admit conjugation with plane Friedmann model through a weak discontinuity and through a shock wave. A possibility of conjugation of plane Friedmann model and the Minkowski space-time through a shock wave of extreme in-- tensity is discussed

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: General relativity theory

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Allgemeine Relativitaetstheorie

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; MANUALS; RIEMANN SPACE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; VECTOR FIELDS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Proceeding from the fundamentals of the Riemann geometry and tensor calculus, the physical laws in the Riemann space are formulated and evaluated. Subsequently, Einstein field equations are derived and all important applications of the theory, including topical problems, are dealt with, especially the Schwarzschild metric, gravitational waves, gravitational collapse, black holes, and cosmological models. Relevant fundamental physical problems are discussed in detail, whereas results based on complex mathematical derivations are merely presented. Connections are made with observations and latest numerical data obtained therefrom. In some more demanding chapters on special vector fields, motion groups, and the Petrov classification, methods particularly fruitful in modern research are considered

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Lewis, S.M. (Center for Theoretical Physics, Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Maryland, College Park, Maryland 20742)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Two cosmological solutions of Regge calculus

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 25(2) p. 306-312; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jan 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MINKOWSKI SPACE; REGGE CALCULUS; UNIVERSE; VECTOR FIELDS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Two cosmological solutions of Regge calculus are presented which correspond to the flat Friedmann-Robertson-Walker and the Kasner solutions of general relativity. By taking advantage of the symmetries that are present, I am able to show explicitly that a limit of Regge calculus does yield Einstein's equations for these cases. The method of averaging these equations when taking limits is important, especially for the Kasner model. I display the leading error term that arises from keeping the Regge equations in discrete form rather than using their continuum limit. In particular, this work shows that for the ''Reggeized'' Friedmann model the minimum volume is a velocity-dominated singularity as in the continuum Friedmann model. However, unlike the latter, the Regge version has a nonzero minimum volume

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SPIN; SPINORS; SUPERGRAVITY; SUPERSYMMETRY; TENSORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The conditions necessary for a solution of the supergravity field equations with infinitesimal spin-3/2 field are determined to be a pure gauge transformation of an Einstein vacuum field. The analysis depends on the Petrov classification of the curvature tensor and uses two-component spinor calculus. For general type I, the type II, and type D, the necessary conditions found are also shown to be sufficient, and the explicit form of the gauge transformation can be given. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

Gravitation</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0001-7701</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 13(9) p. 817-828.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1100" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="00389" assignment="indexer">analytical solution</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03899" assignment="indexer">gauge invariance</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09368" assignment="indexer">spin</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09377" assignment="indexer">spinors</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="19859" assignment="indexer">supergravity</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="20118" assignment="indexer">supersymmetry</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09910" assignment="indexer">tensors</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="00410" assignment="upposted">angular momentum</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="04834" assignment="upposted">invariance principles</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="07197" assignment="upposted">particle properties</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09719" assignment="upposted">symmetry</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The conditions necessary for a solution of the supergravity field equations with infinitesimal spin-3/2 field are determined to be a pure gauge transformation of an Einstein vacuum field. The analysis depends on the Petrov classification of the curvature tensor and uses two-component spinor calculus. For general type I, the type II, and type D, the necessary conditions found are also shown to be sufficient, and the explicit form of the gauge transformation can be given. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="GB">United Kingdom</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Coomer, G.C.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Cincinnati Univ., OH (USA)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Some properties of spatially homogeneous spacetimes

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: 1979; 133 p; ; University Microfilms Order No. 80-02,428; Thesis (Ph. D.).

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: AGE ESTIMATION; BACKGROUND RADIATION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RADIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This paper discusses two features of the universe which are influenced in a fundamental way by the spacetime geometry of the universe. The first is the growth of density fluctuations in the early stages of the evolution of the universe. The second is the propagation of electromagnetic radiation in the universe. A spatially homogeneous universe is assumed in both discussions. The gravitational instability theory of galaxy formation is investigated for a viscous fluid and for a charged, conducting fluid with a magnetic field added as a perturbation. It is found that the growth rate of density perturbations in both cases is lower than in the perfect fluid case. Spatially homogeneous but nonisotropic spacetimes are investigated next. Two perfect fluid solutions of Einstein's field equations are found which have spacelike hypersurfaces with Bianchi type II geometry. An expression for the spectrum of the cosmic microwave background radiation in a spatially homogeneous but nonisotropic universe is found. The expression is then used to determine the angular distribution of the intensity of the radiation in the simpler of the two solutions. When accepted values of the matter density and decoupling temperature are inserted into this solution, values for the age of the universe and the time of decoupling are obtained which agree reasonably well with the values of the standard model of the universe

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1979

meta.content: Axially symmetric Brans-Dicke solutions

meta.name: Source

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; AXIAL SYMMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; KERR METRIC; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A scheme is presented which extends Ernst's concise unified derivation of the axially symmetric solutions of Einstein's field equations to the case of the Brans-Dicke theory. The method is applied to obtain Tomimatsu-Sato type solutions of the Brans-Dicke theory and the analogues of Schwarzschild and Kerr solutions are rediscovered. (author)

meta.content: January 1980

meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; INTERACTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Theory of direct interparticle gravitational interaction is constructed on the basis of principle of the Fokker action. It is shown that in the first approximation according to the interaction constant and for background metrics satisfying condition Rsub(μν)=0, the given formulation of the gravitational theory results in equations of motion in the form of geodesics equations in some Riemann effective space-time and in identical accomlishment of the Einstein equations

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Marek, J.; Sloane, A. (University Coll. of Wales, Aberystwyth (UK))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A finite rotating body in general relativity

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; KERR METRIC; SINGULARITY; SYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The Kerr metric, which is the simplest example of the Tomimatsu-Sato family of solutions of Einstein's vacuum field equations, is written in Lewis' extension of the canonical co-ordinates of Weyl for stationary axially symmetric fields. An anisotropic interior solution for the Kerr metric is constructed and examined and is found to be free of all singularities. The principal value of the energy tensor corresponding to positive matter density is positive everywhere and is much greater than the other three principal values. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1979

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Barrow, J.D.; Silk, J. (Department of Physics, University of California at Berkeley)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Growth structures in a Friedmann universe

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Astrophysical Journal; v. 250(2) p. 432-449; ISSN 0004-637X; 15 Nov 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANISOTROPY; BARYONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELLIPTICAL CONFIGURATION; EXPANSION; GALACTIC EVOLUTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; ROTATION; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; HADRONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Motivated by observational evidence for the existence of flattened or striated structures of very large scale (approx.100 Mpc) in the universe, we study the evolution of nonspherical structures. We set up equations to describe the evolution of a rotating, dust ellipsoid in an expanding universe. We derive solutions for the shape and density evolutions as the ellipsoid expands along with a Friedmann background universe and show that deviations from spherical symmetry are preserved by adiabatic expansion. Analytic expressions are derived to describe the nonlinear evolution of pressure-free ellipsoids. We calculate details of ''pancake'' formation which are relevant for realistic theories of galaxy and cluster formation. In particular, the density collapse at turnaround and the collapse velocity at pancake formation are found to be reduced relative to the spherical case if the initial fluctuations are anisotropic: this may affect kinematic determinations of Ω in the local supercluster and also enable galaxies with massive halos to form during the fragmentation of pancakes whose dynamics are dominated by massive neutrinos. Significant deviations from spherical symmetry in the baryon irregularity spectrum might also be naturally associated with primordial isothermal inhomogeneities in a Friedmann universe and their possible origin at the epoch of ''grand unification.'' An exact model for a general relativistic pancake collapse is given, based on an exact solution to Einstein's equations found by Szekeres. This collapse does not pass through a series of ellipsoids and has no symmetries

meta.name: Abstract1
meta.content: iven, based on an exact solution to Einstein's equations found by Szekeres. This collapse does not pass through a series of ellipsoids and has no symmetries

meta.content: January 1981

We set up equations to describe the evolution of a rotating, dust ellipsoid in an expanding universe. Significant deviations from spherical symmetry in the baryon irregularity spectrum might also be naturally associated with primordial isothermal inhomogeneities in a Friedmann universe and their possible origin at the epoch of ''grand unification.'' An exact model for a general relativistic pancake collapse is given, based on an exact solution to Einstein's equations found by Szekeres. This collapse does not pass through a series of ellipsoids and has no symmetries</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The topics of the monograph are: differential geometry in general relativity, the equivalence principle, the Einstein field equations, the Schwarzschild solution and classical tests, weak fields, the post-newtonian approximation, neutron stars and rotating black holes and binary X-ray sources. (WL)

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Stavroulakis, Nikias (U.E.R. des Sciences de Limoges (France))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Hidden parameters in the potentials of static fields

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Parametres caches dans les potentiels des champs statiques

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Annales de la Fondation Louis de Broglie; v. 6(4) p. 287-327; ISSN 0182-4295; 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC FIELDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; NONMEASURABLE VARIABLES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: According to the classical potentials of Newton and Coulomb, a charged ball behaves as if all of its mass and all of its charge were concentrated at the centre. This simple picture is surely inadequate for the study of the behaviour of the field in the neighbourhood of the centre. The present paper aims at providing a new approach to this problem, particularly interesting for the microphysics, by means of the General Theory of Relativity. It is mainly concerned with establishing new solutions of Einstein's equations, which introduce new parameters (hidden parameters with respect to the classical model) associated with the spatial extension of the matter and the charges. Thus the obtained determination for the gravitational and electrostatic field allows us to get rid of the shortcomings of the classical scheme

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

Fond. Louis de Broglie</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0182-4295</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 6(4) p. 287-327.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1100" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02967" assignment="indexer">electric fields</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11998" assignment="indexer">gravitational fields</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="23404" assignment="indexer">nonmeasurable variables</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">According to the classical potentials of Newton and Coulomb, a charged ball behaves as if all of its mass and all of its charge were concentrated at the centre. This simple picture is surely inadequate for the study of the behaviour of the field in the neighbourhood of the centre. The present paper aims at providing a new approach to this problem, particularly interesting for the microphysics, by means of the General Theory of Relativity. It is mainly concerned with establishing new solutions of Einstein's equations, which introduce new parameters (hidden parameters with respect to the classical model) associated with the spatial extension of the matter and the charges. Thus the obtained determination for the gravitational and electrostatic field allows us to get rid of the shortcomings of the classical scheme</abstract> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="fr">Selon les potentiels classiques de Newton et de Coulomb une charge spherique se comporte comme si sa masse et sa charge etaient concentrees au centre. Cette description est inadequate pour l'etude du champ dans le voisinage du centre. On presente une nouvelle approche de ce probleme au moyen de la theorie de la relativite generale et particulierement interessante en microphysique. On etablit de nouvelles solutions aux equations d'Einstein qui introduisent de nouveaux parametres (parametres caches par rapport au modele classique) associees a une extension spatiale des charges et de la matiere. Nous obtenons ainsi une determination du champ gravitationel et electrostatique qui nous permet de nous debarasser des defauts du modele classique</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="FR">France</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANGULAR VELOCITY; COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; EUCLIDEAN SPACE; FOUR-BODY PROBLEM; GRAVITATION; KERR FIELD; KERR METRIC; LORENTZ TRANSFORMATIONS; POTENTIALS; VECTORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MANY-BODY PROBLEM; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE; TENSORS; VELOCITY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Using a covariant method the Kerr geometry is analyzed. Types of motion are associated with preferred systems of observers, which are freely read off the metric. By using generalized Lorentz transformations one system can be transformed into the other. Forces of deformation due to the differential rotation law act on a local non-rotating observer. Field equations and equations of motion can be formulated in a way like those of the theory of electrodynamics and mechanics of continua. Thus the theory of Kerr is easier to understand. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.content: Krechet, V.G.; Sandina, I.V. (Yaroslavskij Gosudarstvennyj Pedagogicheskij Inst. (USSR))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Self-gravitating wave fields in the Gedel space

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Samogravitiruyushchie volnovye polya v prostranstve Gedelya

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika; v. 24(10) p. 59-63; ISSN 0021-3411; Oct 1981; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics Journal (USA).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DIRAC EQUATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SCALAR FIELDS; SPIN; VECTOR FIELDS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Properties of self-gravitating wave fields of integer spin (scalar and vector) compatible with the Gedel type space are investigated. Solutions of combined sets of equations for the Einstein gravitational field and corresponding wave fields in the Gedel metrics have been obtained. For the scalar field obtained were solutions for the different types of Lagrangians of interaction of the gravitational and scalar fields. It is shown that in the case of the massive vector field the obtained relations between constants within the framework of the ''strong'' gravitation theory result in a classical expression for the spin of elementary particles

meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SCALAR FIELDS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; SURFACES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTERACTIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Junction conditions are formulated in an invariant manner for the jumps in the gravitational and scalar fields across a singular time-like hypersurface in the Brans-Dicke theory of gravity. The equations of motion for singular hypersurfaces are also derived, and an exact solution of the Brans-Dicke field equations is presented which represents a static spherical shell of perfect fluid. (author)

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS; CAUCHY PROBLEM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; LOCALITY; METRICS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We consider the vacuum Einstein equations on R4 with initial data on the hyperplane X0 = 0 which I call Σ. The initial data on Σ consists of a complete riemannian metric g and a 2-covariant symmetric tensor field k such that the pair (g,k) satisfies the initial value constraints. The local-in-time problem is to find an open set Ω contains or eqal or R4, Ω contains Σ, and on this set a Lorentz metric γ, solution to the vacuum Einstein equations in Ω, such that (g,k) are respectively the first and second fundamental forms of Σ relative to γ and (Ω, γ) is a globally hyperbolic spacetime [Σ is a Cauchy surface of (Ω,γ)]. (orig./HSI)

meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MATHEMATICS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A mechanism of spontaneous compactification, based on a requiement of parallelizability of gauge fields potentials in relation to general (riemann and gauge) connection that results in the connection of the group of gauge fields transformations with the holonomy group of iemann connection is considered. A lagrangian is considered corresponding to vacuum state of all fields except of Eisntein fields and gauge fields. The lagrangian includes a spontaneous transition with flat space transformation into compact symmetrical spaces at n=3 for time-like and at n>4 for space-like additional measurements. Gauge fields providing the mechanism of spontaneous compactification during interaction with Einstein fields reffer to the gauge group coinciding with the group of Riemann connection holonomy

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Interacting scalar and electromagnetic fields

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Vzaimodejstvuyushchie skalyarnoe i ehlektromagnotnoe polya

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Problems on gravitation theory and elementary particles. No. 12

meta.name: Source

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; ENERGY DENSITY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; INTERACTIONS; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; SCALAR FIELDS; SYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The interaction of the massless scalar and electromagnetic fields with account of the eigen gravitational field evidently depending on the potentials of the electromagnetic field is considered. Spherically-symmetric and flat-symmetric exact solutions of a set of Einstein equations and the corresponding field equations at arbitrary dependence of the term describing interaction on the invariant I=Qsub(α)Qsup(2) (Qsub(α)- components of the vector-potential of the electromagnetic field) are obtained. Interactions of the polynominal type resulting in the non-linear equation of the electromagnetic field with the gradual non-linearity are analyzed. A model of interaction with locking property in the presence of the Heulock C-field is considered in the flat-symmetrical metrics. Solutions with localized final energy of the system of material fields are shown to exist. The regularity role of the eigen gravitational field in the process of formation of field configurations with final energy is shown by comparison with the corresponding solutions in the flat space-time

meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: To a physical interpretation of a weak gravitational field in GRT

meta.name: Title
meta.content: K fizicheskoj interpretatsii slabogo gravitatsionnogo polya v OTO

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Problems on gravitation theory and elementary particles. No. 12

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Stanyukovich, K.P. (ed.); p. 111-121; 1981; p. 111-121; Ehnergoizdat; Moscow; 3 refs.

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; MINKOWSKI SPACE; RELATIVITY THEORY; TEST PARTICLES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The problem of separation of Newton components of weak vacuum gravitational fields is discussed. Chronometric- invariant (CI) characteristics of space-time and the corresponding Newton values are compared in the fixed systems of reference. Attention is paid to the following facts. ''Weak'' sources of weak gravitational fields do not interact gravitationally. If the CI characteristics of vacuum space- time permit series expansion in 1/c powers then the coefficients at odd 1/c powers are connected with the presence of non-gravitational material fields inside the sources. Masses producing gravitational field may not be the sources of gravitational waves in the form of which this field manifests itself. Perspectives of detecting laboratory gravitational waves are discussed: the simplest metrics of plane wave is considered in the quasi-inertial reference system; the flowsheet of the generator of this wave is suggested; relativistic oscillation of a test massive particle is calculated in the postnewtonian approximation. The numerical evaluations show that attempts of mechanical detection of laboratory gravitational waves are hopeless

meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; INTERFACES; MATTER; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Earlier work on the problem of junction conditions is briefly reviewed. An analytical formalism is developed to deal with the occurrence of jump discontinuities in the gsub(μν) or their first derivatives across a hypersurface Σ. It is shown that the equations of relativity remain meaningful at Σ, even when Σ does not inherit a unique intrinsic geometry, so that the gsub(μν) are discontinuous across Σ in natural coordinates. The spherically symmetric surface layer at the Schwarzschild-Minkowski junction is used to illustrate these techniques, and to establish rigorously the existence of C0 solutions of the Einstein equations and the conservation equations. The possible validity of relativity at the microscopic level is examined, and it is concluded that, if relativity is valid at the microscopic level, then it is likely that the gsub(μν) are not globally continuously differentiable. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Explaining the large numbers by a hierarchy of ''universes'': a unified theory of strong and gravitational interactions

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (A2100); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUIVALENCE PRINCIPLE; FIELD THEORIES; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; HADRONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; QUARKS; STRONG INTERACTIONS; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INTERACTIONS; POSTULATED PARTICLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: By assuming covariance of physical laws under (discrete) dilatations, strong and gravitational interactions have been described in a unified way. In terms of the (additional, discrete) ''dilatational'' degree of freedom, our cosmos as well as hadrons can be considered as different states of the same system, or rather as similar systems. Moreover, a discrete hierarchy can be defined of ''universes'' which are governed by force fields with strengths inversely proportional to the ''universe'' radii. Inside each ''universe'' an equivalence principle holds, so that its characteristic field can be geometrized there. It is thus easy to derive a whole ''numerology'', i.e. relations among numbers analogous to the so-called Weyl-Eddington-Dirac ''large numbers''. For instance, the ''Planck mass'' happens to be nothing but the (average) magnitude of the strong charge of the hadron quarks. However, our ''numerology'' connects the (gravitational) macrocosmos with the (strong) microcosmos, rather than with the electromagnetic ones (as, e.g., in Dirac's version). Einstein-type scaled equations (with ''cosmological'' term) are suggested for the hadron interior, which - incidentally - yield a (classical) quark confinement in a very natural way and are compatible with the ''asymptotic freedom''. At last, within a ''bi-scale'' theory, further equations are proposed that provide a priori a classical field theory of strong interactions (between different hadrons). The relevant sections are 5.2, 7 and 8. (author)

meta.content: fferent hadrons). The relevant sections are 5.2, 7 and 8. (author)
