meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Green, M.A.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Toronto Univ., Ontario (Canada)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Space-time structure and the origin of physical law

meta.name: Source
meta.content: 1980; 137 p; CTOM--47069; ; Available from Canadian Theses on Microfiche Service, National Library of Canada, Ottawa K1A 0N4; Thesis (Ph. D.).

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RELATIVITY THEORY; SPACE-TIME; TOPOLOGY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In the first part of this theses the author adopts a traditional world view, with space-time a topologically simple geometrical manifold, matter being represented by smooth classical fields, and space a Riemannian submanifold of space-time. It is shown how to characterize the space-time geometry in terms of fields defined on three-dimensional space. Accepting a finite number of the fields induced on space as independent initial data, a procedure is given for constructing dynamical and constraint equations which will propagate these fields forward in time. When the initial data are restricted to include only the hypersurface metric and the extrinsic curvature, the resulting equations combine to form the Einstein gravitational field equations with the cosmological term. The synthesis of gravitational and quantum physics is approached by proposing that the objective world underlying the perceived world is a four-dimensional topological manifold w, with no physically significant field structure and an unconstrianed and complex global topology. Conventional space-time is then a topologically simple replacement manifold for w. A preliminary outline of the correspondence is presented, based on a similarity between a natural graphical representation of 2 and the Feynman graphs of quantum field theory

meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Bampi, F. (Genoa Univ. (Italy). Ist. Matematico)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Linearization procedure for cylindrically and axially symmetric space-times

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 14(5) p. 429-438; ISSN 0001-7701; May 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: AXIAL SYMMETRY; CYLINDRICAL CONFIGURATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; SPACE-TIME; TRANSFORMATIONS; VACUUM STATES; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: An investigation of the vacuum Einstein gravitational field equations for cylindrically and axially symmetric space-times is presented which leads to an equivalent differential system involving a simple nonlinearity only. The case when this equivalent system is linear is analyzed in detail and two methods for generating solutions of the Einstein vacuum equations are set up. As a result, in the axially symmetric case the linearity of the equivalent system characterizes completely the Kramer-Neugebauer transforms of Papapetrou line elements. Accordingly, Weyl solutions are shown to generate exhaustively both Lewis and van Stockum solutions. Analogous results are obtained also in the cylindrically symmetric case. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: To the distant observer, who uses measuring instruments not affected by gravity, gravitational repulsion can occur anywhere in the Schwarzschild field. It depends on the relationship between the transverse and radial Schwarzschild velocities. On the other hand, local observers, whose measuring instruments are affected by gravity, can not detect a positive value for the acceleration of gravity

Rev., D</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0556-2821</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 25(12) p. 3191-3194.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1100" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="12701" assignment="indexer">equations of motion</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11998" assignment="indexer">gravitational fields</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08872" assignment="indexer">schwarzschild metric</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02642" assignment="upposted">differential equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="upposted">metrics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="21631" assignment="upposted">partial differential equations</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">To the distant observer, who uses measuring instruments not affected by gravity, gravitational repulsion can occur anywhere in the Schwarzschild field. It depends on the relationship between the transverse and radial Schwarzschild velocities. On the other hand, local observers, whose measuring instruments are affected by gravity, can not detect a positive value for the acceleration of gravity</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.content: Axially symmetric gravitational two-body problem of Cooperstock, Lim, and Hobill

meta.name: Country

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY; TWO-BODY PROBLEM

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MANY-BODY PROBLEM

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Cooperstock, Lim, and Hobill have constructed and analyzed a model spacetime describing the head-on free-fall from rest of two fluid balls under their mutual gravitational attraction. These authors find a gravitational radiation energy flux having a different dependence on the parameters of the problem than would be expected on the basis of the quadrupole formula. We show that this dependence is due to their having incorrectly solved Einstein's gravitational field equations. The correct solution is consistent with the quadrupole formula

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; HILBERT SPACE; METRICS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SU-2 GROUPS; TENSORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BANACH SPACE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SPACE; SU GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In the last three decades or so many methods to quantize the gravitational field were developed but all of them have led to no, or very little progress. All these methods are shared in the idea of treating gravitation in a similar fashion to either the electromagnetic field or the Yang-Mills field. The author suggests a completely new approach to the notion of quantizing gravity. In this approach the gravitational field is to be described as the Hilbert or the Banach space of the quantized system, whereas all other non-gravitational physical quantities are to be described as operators in the infinite-dimensional space. This idea is in complete harmony with Einstein's notion that gravitation is to be treated differently from other fields and hence led him to identify gravity with the Riemannian geometry of space-time, whereas other non-gravitational fields are left to be described as quantities defined in that Riemannian geometry. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; SPACE; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The author presents a review on the problem of complete separability of variables for the Hamilton-Jacobi equation for geodesics in space-time. Nowadays the problem of separability is not yet completely solved in all minor details and not all separable solutions to Einstein field equations are known. However, the most important facts have been exploited and most of the remaining problems are in progress. It may be said that the theory of separation of variables has finally reached a satisfactory level of development. The reader will find an historical introduction to separability in general relativity, whose history is considerably younger than the separability of the Hamilton-Jacobi equation. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1982

meta.content: Yamazaki, M. (Kanazawa Univ. (Japan). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The Kerr-Tomimatsu-Sato family of spinning mass solutions

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the second Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Ruffini, R. (ed.) (Rome Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica); International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy); 752 p; ISBN 0 444 86357 5; 1982; p. 371-395; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 2. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Trieste (Italy); 5 - 11 Jul 1979

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; INTEGRALS; KERR METRIC; RECURSION RELATIONS; SINGULARITY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The closed form with an arbitrary positive integer distortion parameter delta of the Kerr-Tomimatsu-Sato family of spinning mass solutions, i.e., stationary axisymmetric, asymptotically flat exact solutions of Einstein's vacuum field equations Rsub(μγ) = 0 is presented. The generalization of the Kerr-Tomimatsu-Sato family of solutions to the case of the arbitrary positive non-integral distortion parameter delta is conjectured. Some analytic properties of the family of solutions are studied. It is shown that all ring singularities are of first order and all ergosurfaces are simple zeros of metric functions f. The charged Kerr-Tomimatsu-Sato family of solutions is also given in the closed form with an arbitrary positive integer distortion parameter delta. It is shown that the Christodoulou-Ruffini mass formula of the Kerr-Newman field or the delta = 1 member of the present family of solutions also holds true in the case of the charged Kerr-Tomimatsu-Sato family of solutions with an arbitary odd integer delta. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We explicitly integrate one of the Einstein field equations describing the stationary and axially symmetric spacetime, whose source is a perfect-fluid, vorticity-free ring of matter orbiting a black hole. This reduces the number of unknown metric functions to three

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; INTEGRALS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; POSTULATED PARTICLES; RADIATIONS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Penrose has given a twistor description of all self-dual complex Riemannian space-times. This construction is modified to characterize all complex Riemannian space-times and all complex teleparallel space-times. This construction may be useful in finding non-self-dual solutions to the gravitational field equations (Einstein's or otherwise) without or with sources. It may also lead to a nonperturbative method for computing path integrals. Whereas Penrose shows that a self-dual space-time may be specified by a deformation of projective twistor space (the set of α planes in complex Minkowski space), it is found that a Riemannian or teleparallel space-time may be described by a deformation of projective ambitwistor space (the set of null geodesics in complex Minkowski space). (author)

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: An attempt is made to show that certain of Essen's views on Special Relativity are distorted because (i) he misunderstands the full import of Einstein's synchronisation procedures; (ii) he mistakenly characterises the 'clock paradox'. It is also suggested that Essen's main controversial view that 'ticks are lost' between two observers, moving uniformly and relatively with respect to each other, is wrong. (author)

meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; PLASMA

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A study is presented of the evolution of helicity-O waves (density waves) on the FRW cosmological background using a two-time scale method for solving the perturbed field equation. The kinetic description is adopted by means of the collisionless Liouville equation self-consistently coupled with Einstein's equations. The rate of growth is obtained from dispersion relations which are studied in the case of a cold gravitational plasma. (author)

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Singularities of sources of the Schwarzschild field

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Osobennosti istochnikov polya Shvartsshil'da

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Acta Physica Polonica. Series B; v. 11(11) p. 783-790; ISSN 0587-4254; 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; RELATIVITY THEORY; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Spherically symmetric solutions of Einstein equations in a one-parameter class of coordinates which generalize the harmonic coordinates are obtained. It is shown that in these coordinates the time component of the source tensor of the Schwarzschild field is proportional to the Dirac delta function while the remaining components vanish. It is shown also that the gravitational momentum of the Schwarzschild field is equal to the sum of the field momentum and the inertial momentum in two coordinate systems only. This equality may be treated as sort of a ''natural'' condition which selects priviledged coordinate system. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

record.content: <html><head><META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head><body><inisrecord> <action trn="PL8200642" type="add" /> <record role="document" source-system="fibre" trn="PL8200642" type="journal" rn="14738888"> <publication> <languages> <language key="ru">Russian</language> </languages> <titles> <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">Singularities of sources of the Schwarzschild field</title> <title type="original" xml:lang="ru">Osobennosti istochnikov polya Shvartsshil'da</title> </titles> <date value="1980--" sici-chronology="1980">1980</date> <country key="PL">Poland</country> <creators and-others="no"> <creator type="personal">Jankiewicz, C.</creator> <creator type="personal">Ampel, R.</creator> <creator type="affiliation">Wyzsza Szkola Pedagogiczna, Rzeszow (Poland)</creator> </creators> <availability inis="no"> <contact>Bibliographic information available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:14738888</contact> </availability> <is-part-of> <journal> <titles> <title type="primary">Acta Physica Polonica. Series B</title> <title type="abbreviated">Acta Phys. Pol., Ser. B</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0587-4254</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 11(11) p. 783-790.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1100" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="00389" assignment="indexer">analytical solution</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02206" assignment="indexer">coordinates</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08416" assignment="indexer">relativity theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08872" assignment="indexer">schwarzschild metric</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="upposted">metrics</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Spherically symmetric solutions of Einstein equations in a one-parameter class of coordinates which generalize the harmonic coordinates are obtained. It is shown that in these coordinates the time component of the source tensor of the Schwarzschild field is proportional to the Dirac delta function while the remaining components vanish. It is shown also that the gravitational momentum of the Schwarzschild field is equal to the sum of the field momentum and the inertial momentum in two coordinate systems only. This equality may be treated as sort of a ''natural'' condition which selects priviledged coordinate system. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="PL">Poland</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Time evolution of pure gravitational waves

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 65(3) p. 894-909; ISSN 0033-068X; Mar 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: AXIAL SYMMETRY; BLACK HOLES; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY LOSSES; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; METRICS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; RADIATIONS; SIMULATION; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Numerical solutions to the Einstein equations in the case of pure gravitational waves are given. The system is assumed to be axially symmetric and non-rotating. The time symmetric initial data and the conformally flat initial data are obtained by solving the constraint equations at t = 0. The time evolution of these initial data depends strongly on the initial amplitude of the gravitational waves. In the case of the low initial amplitude, waves only disperse to null infinity. By comparing the initial gravitational energy with the total energy loss through an γ = constant surface, it is concluded that the Newman-Penrose method and the Gibbon-Hawking method are the most desirable for measuring the energy flux of gravitational radiation numerically. In the case that the initial ratio of the spatial extent of the gravitational waves to the Schwarzschild radius (M/2) is smaller than about 300, the waves collapse by themselves, leading to formation of a black hole. The analytic solutions of the linearized Einstein equations for the pure gravitational waves are also shown. (author)

meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Field momentum, inertial momentum and gravitational momentum of a system of bodies in the post-Newtonian approximation

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Polevoj, inertsial'nyi i gravitatsionnyj impul's sistemy tel v post-n'eyutonovskom priblizhenii

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Acta Physica Polonica. Series B; v. 11(10) p. 717-728; ISSN 0587-4254; 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY; LINEAR MOMENTUM; LORENTZ TRANSFORMATIONS; MANY-BODY PROBLEM; RELATIVITY THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is shwon that in the post-Newtonian approximation the gravitational momentum of a system of point particles is equal to the sum of field momentum and inertial momentum only in two classes of coordinate systems. This equality may be treated as a natural condition on a coordinate system in which the generally covariant Einstein equations are to be solved. (author)

meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This is a review, covering known globally regular solutions describing either vacuum or fields with physically reasonable sources. The largest class is that with static spherical symmetry, but many others are known, even with Λ=0. If Λ is not equal to 0 there is a variety of regular cosmological solutions. (author)

meta.content: General relativity and matter

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; HYPOTHESIS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; WAVE EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The primary aim of this monograph is to present the results of a research study that attempts to fully unify the logical and the mathematical aspects of the theory of general relativity. It views the theory of general relativity not as a theory only of the gravitational force manifestation of matter, but rather as a general theory of matter. This approach proceeds by attempting to fully incorporate the Mach principle into the formalism so as to fuse the gravitational and electromagnetic force manifestations of matter with its inertial manifestations. With this approach it is shown that in accordance with Einstein's original motivation toward a unified field theory, generalization occurs that adds to the predictive capacity of the theory, incorporating the physics of the domain of elementary matter (of microscopic physics) with the domain of astronomy and cosmology; thus this approach unifies manifestations of matter from the domain of fermis (and less) to that of light-years (and greater) in terms of a nonsingular field theory of matter. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: DEC

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A static cosmological model in the Einstein-Cartan theory based on Lyra's modified Riemannian geometry is proposed. It is assumed that the spins of the individual particles composing the fluid are all aligned in the radial direction and observe the very interesting fact that if spin is there in this static Einstein universe, it should be constant and it can be given in terms of central density p0 as K=A=(1/4π)[(8πp0 - 3/R2) + 3/4β2]sup(1/2). The geometry and properties of the model are discussed. (author)

meta.content: January 1982

Gravitation</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0001-7701</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 14(10) p. 823-830.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1500" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="02277" assignment="indexer">cosmological models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02572" assignment="indexer">density</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03565" assignment="indexer">fluids</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03936" assignment="indexer">geometry</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="07204" assignment="indexer">particles</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08554" assignment="indexer">riemann space</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09368" assignment="indexer">spin</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="00410" assignment="upposted">angular momentum</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05907" assignment="upposted">mathematical space</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05908" assignment="upposted">mathematics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="07197" assignment="upposted">particle properties</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="07447" assignment="upposted">physical properties</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09317" assignment="upposted">space</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">A static cosmological model in the Einstein-Cartan theory based on Lyra's modified Riemannian geometry is proposed. It is assumed that the spins of the individual particles composing the fluid are all aligned in the radial direction and observe the very interesting fact that if spin is there in this static Einstein universe, it should be constant and it can be given in terms of central density p<sub>0</sub> as K=A=(1/4π)[(8πp<sub>0</sub> - 3/R<sup>2</sup>) + 3/4β<sup>2</sup>]sup(1/2). The geometry and properties of the model are discussed. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="GB">United Kingdom</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PARTICLE PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A unique class of solutions of the classical spin fluid with zero pressure is obtained. The spin density vanishes at the boundary of the fluid sphere and the gsub(μν) and their derivatives satisfy continuity conditions with the exterior metric. (author)

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Numerical relativity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A, Mathematical and Physical Sciences; v. 384(1787) p. 427-454; ISSN 0080-4630; 8 Dec 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GLOBAL ANALYSIS; INTEGRAL CALCULUS; LIMITING VALUES; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In this, the first of a series of papers on numerical relativity, the characteristic initial value problem is posed in a form suitable for numerical integration. It can be reduced to the solution of two initial value problems for sets of ordinary differential equations (n the initial surfaces) and the solution of two initial value problems for hyperbolic systems of equations, one linear, one quasilinear. The initial data may be specified freely. Subsequent papers will develop numerical solutions of Einstein's equations with use of this formalism. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Experiments in quantum gravity show that Einstein's theory of general relativity is incomplete by a gravitational field stress-energy term in the field equations. The field stress-energy term needed for completion is explicitly given in the case of static fields

meta.content: January 1980

meta.content: Constrained dynamics with applications to Yang-Mills theory, general relativity, classical spin, dual string model

meta.content: CANONICAL TRANSFORMATIONS; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; COMMUTATION RELATIONS; DYNAMICS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRODYNAMICS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; FEYNMAN PATH INTEGRAL; FUNCTIONAL ANALYSIS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEOMETRY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; HAMILTONIAN FUNCTION; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; LECTURES; MAXWELL EQUATIONS; PHASE SPACE; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; RELATIVITY THEORY; SECOND QUANTIZATION; SINGULARITY; STRING MODELS; SYMMETRY; YANG-MILLS THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; INTEGRALS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MATHEMATICS; MECHANICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTIZATION; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This book is an introduction to the Lagrangian formulation of classical mechanics and field theory. After a description of classical regular and singular systems together with the reduced phase space the quantization of constrained systems is described. Then as examples the electromagnetic field, the Yang-Mills theory, the relativistic particle, the relativistic string and Einstein's theory of gravitation are considered. This book is suited for students and scientists who want to get some knowledge about theoretical physics beyond the usual fields teached in the regular courses. (HSI)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Tomimatsu, Akira (Hiroshima Univ., Takehara (Japan). Research Inst. for Theoretical Physics); Sato, Humitaka.

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Multi-soliton solutions of the Einstein equation and the Tomimatsu-Sato metric

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Progress of Theoretical Physics, Supplement; (no.70) p. 215-237; ISSN 0375-9687; Mar 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ANGULAR MOMENTUM; BAECKLUND TRANSFORMATION; BLACK HOLES; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; INVERSE SCATTERING PROBLEM; KERR METRIC; MASS; RED SHIFT; SOLITONS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; QUASI PARTICLES; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We present a new recognition about the Tomimatsu-Sato metric through reviewing the recent study of the stationary and axially symmetric Einstein field equation. We describe some powerful methods of solving the Einstein equation; the Baecklund transformation, the inverse scattering method and any other. These methods derive the so-called multi-soliton solution, which represents the Kerr-NUT metric or a non-linear superposition of several Kerr-NUT metrics aligned along their common rotational axis. The Tomimatsu-Sato metric of delta = N is constructed via a limiting process that the N Kerr metrics with the same mass and angular momentum approach mutually towards their complete overlapping. We investigate the space-time properties of the multi-soliton metric, by taking the two Kerr case as a typical example. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

type="valid" key="17287" assignment="indexer">red shift</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="12811" assignment="indexer">solitons</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="upposted">metrics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08130" assignment="upposted">quasi particles</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="14184" assignment="upposted">transformations</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">We present a new recognition about the Tomimatsu-Sato metric through reviewing the recent study of the stationary and axially symmetric Einstein field equation. We describe some powerful methods of solving the Einstein equation; the Baecklund transformation, the inverse scattering method and any other. These methods derive the so-called multi-soliton solution, which represents the Kerr-NUT metric or a non-linear superposition of several Kerr-NUT metrics aligned along their common rotational axis. The Tomimatsu-Sato metric of delta = N is constructed via a limiting process that the N Kerr metrics with the same mass and angular momentum approach mutually towards their complete overlapping. We investigate the space-time properties of the multi-soliton metric, by taking the two Kerr case as a typical example. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="JP">Japan</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Is gravitation essentially a macroscopic phenomenon

meta.content: Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 29(7) p. 203-206; ISSN 0024-1318; 18 Oct 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; MINKOWSKI SPACE; POISSON EQUATION; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A formalism resembling Einstein's theory is derived from the field equations of the recently published conformal model of hadronic microuniverses. Being an averaged out procedure the implication will be that gravitation as described by GR is essentially a macroscopic phenomen caused by a large-scale distribution of matter and energy. (author)

meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Pandya, P.C.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: London Univ. (UK)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The application of techniques of many body problems and relativistic quantum field theory to the behaviour of matter in a highly condensed state with particular reference to the very early state of the Universe, black-holes and neutron star

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: nd; 575 p; ; Available from British Lending Library, Boston Spa, Wetherby, West Yorks. No. D70186/81; Thesis (Ph.D.).

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; DENSITY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; MANY-BODY PROBLEM; NEUTRON STARS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SCALAR FIELDS; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; STARS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A framework is set up to investigate the superdense state of matter as realized in a Black Hole, a Neutron Star and the Early State of the Universe. A relativistic scalar field Langrangian model of a collapsing star is used to study Einstein's field equation at the semi-classical level. A Special relativistic Green's function equation of transport in close analogy with Boltzmann's equation of transport is developed to study non-equilibrium statistical thermodynamics and a possible quantum field theoretic approach to equilibrium statistical mechanics is outlined. The solutions of the scalar field equation in a given curved space-time are discussed. A Usub(L)(2) x Usub(G)(2) gauge invariant Langrangian model is set up to study degenerate superdense matter as realized in a Neutron Star. Using this model a special relativistic many-body theory is developed in close analogy with non-relativistic many-body theory. (author)

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Lopez, C.A. (Chile Univ., Santiago. Dept. de Fisica)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Rigidly rotating disk as a source of the Kerr geometry

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; DISTRIBUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GEOMETRY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; KERR FIELD; KERR METRIC; RICCI TENSOR; SINGULARITY; STARS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATHEMATICS; METRICS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The theory of distributions is applied to determine the source of the Kerr geometry. The stress-energy tensor is obtained, via Einstein's field equations, by adopting the ''branch cut'' interpretation of the equatorial disk which spans the ring singularity. The stress-energy tensor is thus assumed to be a distribution having its support throughout the disk and along the ring. A simple model, which accounts for the tensor so obtained, is set up. Upon the disk it consists in a mixture of gas and dust rotating as a whole about the symmetry axis with constant angular velocity #betta# = a-1. The linear velocity, in turn, increases from zero at the centre of the disk up to the speed of light on its edge. The energy densities of both perfect fluids have the same absolute value, but are of opposite sign. On the other hand, the source on the ring is made up of dustlike particles having infinite positive energy and a finite radial dipole moment. Although these particles circulate along the ring with the speed of light, they cannot escape because they are pulled by an infinite tension (negative pressure) of the gas lying on the disk. It is further verified that the stress-energy tensor correctly reproduces the values of the mass and angular momentum of the Kerr black hole. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Singularities and evolution of the Szekeres cosmological models

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 26(12) p. 3315-3326; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Dec 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; PERTURBATION THEORY; RICCI TENSOR; RIEMANN SPACE; SINGULARITY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We present a new formulation of the two classes of Szekeres solutions of the Einstein field equations, which unifies the solutions as regards their dynamics, and relates them to the Friedmann-Robertson-Walker (FRW) cosmological models in a particularly transparent way. This reformulation enables us to give a general analysis of the scalar polynomial curvature singularities of the solutions, and of their evolution in time. In particular, the solutions which are close to an FRW model near the initial singularity, or in the late stages of evolution, are identified

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Burt, P.B. (Clemson Univ., SC (USA). Dept. of Physics and Astronomy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Quantized gravity, persistent interactions and mass generation

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 30(11) p. 345-349; ISSN 0024-1318; 14 Mar 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COUPLING CONSTANTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; MASS; MATRIX ELEMENTS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Both quantum theory and classical gravitational theory as described by Einstein's equations include self interactions. Quantized gravity, in the form of a quantum field theory, would, therefore, be expected to exhibit effects of self interactions in a unique way. An example of a quantum field theory with persistent self interactions is discussed in order to illustrate how a proposed new quantum field theory of gravity might include the intrinsically nonlinear self interactions. One result would be the spontaneous generation of mass in a theory for which linearized excitations are massless. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Neutrino-generated static space-times

meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ASTROPHYSICS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; NEUTRINOS; SPACE-TIME; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LEPTONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The interaction between neutrinos and gravitation is considered by studying the Einstein-Dirac (Weyl) equations. For simplicity only plane symmetric space-times are discussed. Exact, static solutions to the Einstein-Dirac equations are derived. Although the models derived are not of direct astrophysical interest, they are simple and point out explicit properties of the theory. (author)

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Vlasov, A.A.; Denisov, V.I. (Moskovskij Gosudarstvennyj Univ. (USSR))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Einstein formula for gravitational radiation does not follow from general relativity theory

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Formula Ehjnshtejna dlya gravitatsionnogo izlucheniya ne yavlyaetsya sledstviem obshchej teorii otnositel'nosti

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Teoreticheskaya i Matematicheskaya Fizika; v. 53(3) p. 406-418; ISSN 0564-6162; Dec 1982; For English translation see the journal Theoretical and Mathematical Physics (USA).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CONSERVATION LAWS; COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY CONSERVATION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; RIEMANN SPACE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; RADIATIONS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is shown that the intensity of gravitational radiation and complete intensity defined in general relativity theory according to Einstein are dependent of the choice of coordinate system and as a result they may vanish or even become negative. Hence the well-known Einstein quadrupole formula which is as a rule used for calculations in general relativity theory is not a consequence of general relativity theory and is not contained in the latter. This result is just one particular consequence of the general statement about the absence of energy-momentum conservation laws for a system including the matter and the gravitational field in general relativity theory

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Characteristic initial data and wavefront singularities in general relativity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A, Mathematical and Physical Sciences; v. 385(1789) p. 345-371; ISSN 0080-4630; 8 Feb 1983

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; WAVE PROPAGATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The structure of singularities (caustics), self-intersections of wavefronts (null hypersurfaces) and wavefront families (null coordinates) in arbitrary space-times is discussed in detail and illustrated by explicit examples of stable wavefront singularities in Minkowski space. It is shown how characteristic initial data determine the caustics and the self-intersections of the characteristics of Einstein's field equations. (author)

meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Cattell, D.F.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Temple Univ., Philadelphia, PA (USA)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Neutrino, Maxwell and scalar fields in cylindrical and spherical relativistic spaces

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: 1981; 226 p; ; University Microfilms Order No. 81-24,556; Thesis (Ph. D.).

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CYLINDRICAL CONFIGURATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; NEUTRINOS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; SYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LEPTONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We discuss the quantum-mechanical theory of neutrino, Maxwell and zero-mass scalar fields treated as test fields in two different fixed background spacetimes representing respectively spatial cylindrical and spherical symmetries. The metrics for these spacetimes are exact solutions of the Einstein gravitational field equations. In the first case the background metric is that of the static, cylindrically symmetric magnetic or plasm universe whose theory has been given by Melvin. In the second case the background metric is that of the Schwarzschild geometry external to an isolated spherically-symmetric source of gravity. The c-number quantum mechanical equations of neutrino, Maxwell and zero-mass scalar fields (generalized to curved spacetime) are solved by means of a procedure developed by Cohen and Kegeles. This procedure is applicable only in algebrically special spacetimes which admit a congruence of shear-free null geodesics along the repeated principal null vector of the Weyl tensor; this condition is met for both of the spacetimes under consideration. The main instrument of the procedure is the Cohen-Kegeles (CK) scalar wave equation for test fields of helicity h. The solutions of this equation, when differentiated in a way specified by the CK procedure, give the spinor components of the test field in question. We rewrite the CK equations using the updated Geroch-Held-Penrose (GHP) formalism

meta.content: January 1981

The c-number quantum mechanical equations of neutrino, Maxwell and zero-mass scalar fields (generalized to curved spacetime) are solved by means of a procedure developed by Cohen and Kegeles. This procedure is applicable only in algebrically special spacetimes which admit a congruence of shear-free null geodesics along the repeated principal null vector of the Weyl tensor; this condition is met for both of the spacetimes under consideration. The main instrument of the procedure is the Cohen-Kegeles (CK) scalar wave equation for test fields of helicity h. The solutions of this equation, when differentiated in a way specified by the CK procedure, give the spinor components of the test field in question. We rewrite the CK equations using the updated Geroch-Held-Penrose (GHP) formalism</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.content: Wu, Y.; Ge, M. (Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, New Jersey 08540)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A simplified derivation of the Geroch group in two-dimensional reduced gravity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GRAVITATION; METRICS; SYMMETRY GROUPS; TENSORS; TRANSFORMATIONS; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: By generalizing our previous treatment of hidden symmetry in two-dimensional chiral models, a simple and explicit approach is proposed to the Geroch group for the vacuum Einstein equations with the metric tensor depending only on two variables (''two-dimensional reduced gravity''). An infinite number of infinitesimal transformations for the metric tensor preserving the equations of motion are summarized by an explicit parametric transformation and the commutators among them are calculated in a simple and straightforward way. These transformations and their group structure are further identified to be those of the well-known Geroch group

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Redmount, I.H. (Theoretical Astrophysics 130-33, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, California 91125)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Geometric constraints on nonsingular, momentarily static, axisymmetric systems in general relativity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 27(4) p. 699-718; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Feb 1983

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; VACUUM STATES; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This paper attempts to examine the relationship between system size and gravitational collapse for the case of axial symmetry. The approach here is to construct noncollapsing systems, with momentarily static matter interiors and static vacuum exteriors, and to find limitations on the validity of the construction. Specifically, the exteriors are static, axisymmetric, asymptotically flat, vacuum geometries, described by Weyl solutions of the Einstein field equations. These solutions have singular sources (naked singularities, except for the Schwarzschild solution); here, regions of the Weyl solutions containing the singularities are replaced by momentarily static material bodies. These are described by axisymmetric solutions of Brill's time-symmetric initial-value equation with non-negative energy density, joining smoothly to the Weyl geometries at the bodies' boundaries. The consistency requirements of such a construction limit the choice of surfaces in the exterior geometry suitable as matter/vacuum boundaries; general constraints on the boundary location and geometry are derived here. For the explicit examples of the GAMMA metric and the Bach-Weyl ring metric as exteriors, these constraints forbid the boundary surface to be arbitrarily near the Weyl singularity. The ''hoop conjecture'' demands, roughly, that the largest circumference of the boundary surface of such a noncollapsing system always exceed a limit of the order of the system's mass. The specific examples studied here are all consistent with the hoop conjecture, but they show that the boundary constraints derived in this paper are not in general related to boundary surface size and thus that these constraints do not embody the hoop conjecture

meta.name: Abstract1
meta.content: the system's mass. The specific examples studied here are all consistent with the hoop conjecture, but they show that the boundary constraints derived in this paper are not in general related to boundary surface size and thus that these constraints do not embody the hoop conjecture

These are described by axisymmetric solutions of Brill's time-symmetric initial-value equation with non-negative energy density, joining smoothly to the Weyl geometries at the bodies' boundaries. The consistency requirements of such a construction limit the choice of surfaces in the exterior geometry suitable as matter/vacuum boundaries; general constraints on the boundary location and geometry are derived here. For the explicit examples of the GAMMA metric and the Bach-Weyl ring metric as exteriors, these constraints forbid the boundary surface to be arbitrarily near the Weyl singularity. meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Local symmetries of the Einstein-Yang-Mills theory as phase-space transformations

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 27(4) p. 757-763; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Feb 1983

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; HAMILTONIANS; PHASE SPACE; SCALAR FIELDS; YANG-MILLS THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; QUANTUM OPERATORS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: For Einstein's theory of gravitation coupled to scalar and Yang-Mills sources we implement local symmetries as canonical transformations in a phase space. This is carried out without any action principle. The procedure allows one to rederive the supermomentum for the Einstein-scalar fields, and both the supermomentum and super-Hamiltonian of the coupled Einstein-Yang-Mills system. For the latter theory it turns out that general coordinate transformations alone cannot be realized in a phase space

meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Henriksen, R.N.; Emslie, A.G.; Wesson, P.S. (Astronomy Group, Department of Physics, Queen's University at Kingston, Kingston, Ontario K7L 3N6 Canada)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Space-times with constant vacuum energy density and a conformal Killing vector

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 27(6) p. 1219-1227; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Mar 1983

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; METRICS; PARTICLE PRODUCTION; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY BREAKING; UNIVERSE; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INTERACTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We find a class of solutions to the Einstein field equations with constant vacuum energy density (''cosmological constant'') that has a similarity symmetry of the second kind. We show this symmetry to be a global conformal symmetry. Nontrivial analytic solutions are given and one in particular (exhibiting intrinsic symmetry) is shown to evolve to a nonempty Robertson-Walker space-time with ''steady-state'' metric. This is found to be due to particle production associated with the negative matter pressure that is required by the assumed symmetry. These models can describe, classically, an origin of the Universe in terms of particle production from the vacuum, driving an exponential (de Sitter) expansion. This solution is inhomogeneous and anisotropic, but tends to homogeneity and isotropy at early times and large distances, and at late times and small distances. The solution therefore corresponds to the outward motion of a spherical disturbance which distorts the local homogeneity and isotropy in an asymptotically homogeneous and isotropic universe. The limiting homogeneous and isotropic forms are discussed

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

record.content: <html><head><META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head><body><inisrecord> <action trn="US8313734" type="add" /> <record role="document" source-system="fibre" trn="US8313734" type="journal" rn="14781598"> <publication> <titles> <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">Space-times with constant vacuum energy density and a conformal Killing vector</title> </titles> <date value="1983-03-15" sici-chronology="19830315">15 Mar 1983</date> <country key="US">United States</country> <creators and-others="no"> <creator type="personal">Henriksen, R.N.</creator> <creator type="personal">Emslie, A.G.</creator> <creator type="personal">Wesson, P.S.</creator> <creator type="affiliation">Astronomy Group, Department of Physics, Queen's University at Kingston, Kingston, Ontario K7L 3N6 Canada</creator> </creators> <availability inis="no"> <contact>Bibliographic information available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:14781598</contact> </availability> <is-part-of> <journal> <titles> <title type="primary">Physical Review. D, Particles Fields</title> <title type="abbreviated">Phys. Rev., D</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0556-2821</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 27(6) p. 1219-1227.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1500" /> <category type="common" level="secondary" key="A1100" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="02277" assignment="indexer">cosmological models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="20942" assignment="indexer">energy density</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="indexer">metrics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11507" assignment="indexer">particle production</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09720" assignment="indexer">symmetry breaking</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="10631" assignment="indexer">universe</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11532" assignment="indexer">vacuum states</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="04787" assignment="upposted">interactions</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="12499" assignment="upposted">particle interactions</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">We find a class of solutions to the Einstein field equations with constant vacuum energy density (''cosmological constant'') that has a similarity symmetry of the second kind. We show this symmetry to be a global conformal symmetry. Nontrivial analytic solutions are given and one in particular (exhibiting intrinsic symmetry) is shown to evolve to a nonempty Robertson-Walker space-time with ''steady-state'' metric. This is found to be due to particle production associated with the negative matter pressure that is required by the assumed symmetry. These models can describe, classically, an origin of the Universe in terms of particle production from the vacuum, driving an exponential (de Sitter) expansion. This solution is inhomogeneous and anisotropic, but tends to homogeneity and isotropy at early times and large distances, and at late times and small distances. The solution therefore corresponds to the outward motion of a spherical disturbance which distorts the local homogeneity and isotropy in an asymptotically homogeneous and isotropic universe. The limiting homogeneous and isotropic forms are discussed</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Surface integrals and the gravitational action

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 16(8) p. 1661-1668; ISSN 0305-4470; 1 Jun 1983

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; INTEGRALS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The modifications needed to free the Einstein-Hilbert action of gravitation from all second derivatives of fields are discussed and the resulting action applicable to either metric or vierbein variables explicitly given. Variation of this action leads to Einstein's equations without boundary conditions. It vanishes for flat space-time and contains one arbitrary real parameter. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: By exploiting the conformal symmetry inherent in the Einstein theory we construct a more general form for the Dirac constraints involving an arbitrary function. This more general form is required if a canonically quantized theory is to accommodate renormalization

meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Ishikawa, Ken-ichi; Miyashita, Tetsuo (Waseda Univ., Tokyo (Japan). Science and Engineering Research Lab.)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Classification of Petrov type D empty Einstein spaces with diverging null geodesic congruences

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 67(3) p. 828-843; ISSN 0033-068X; Mar 1982

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In terms of Eddington-Finkelstein coordinates, we give the most general form of the line element for all type D empty spaces. The merits of our form are that this metric contains special space-times without a uniform acceleration in a non-sigular form and this form makes it possible a systematic survey for the type D spaces. We perform a classification of all type D empty spaces as Lorentz space-times. In the most general case, the classification leads to nine classes, some of which can be reduced to the four classes of the Kinnersley class II in a limiting case. Moreover in another limiting case the most general case can be reduced to the Kineersley class IIIa, some of which can cover all static classes discussed by Ehlers and Kundt. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Grensing, D.; Grensing, G. (Universitat Kiel, Fachbereich Physik, D-2300 Kiel, West Germany)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: General relativity as a gauge theory of the Poincare group, the symmetric momentum tensor of both matter and gravity, and gauge-fixing conditions

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 28(2) p. 286-296; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jul 1983

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRODYNAMICS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; LORENTZ TRANSFORMATIONS; METRICS; POINCARE GROUPS; SPACE-TIME; SPIN

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is shown that a consistent gauging of the Poincare group is capable of including Einstein's general relativity. This statement holds for matter particles of arbitrary spin, provided the nontrivial part of the vierbein is taken as the fundamental gravitational field, thus giving rise to a known modification of the original theory. Since the gauge approach implies that gravitation is an ordinary field theory over flat space, the standard prescriptions for calculating the asymmetric momentum tensor of both matter and gravitation are available. Applying Belinfante's flat-space symmetrization procedure to the latter, we prove that the symmetrization of the asymmetric matter tensor just gives the dynamically defined symmetric matter tensor, whereas the symmetrization of the asymmetric gravitational momentum tensor leads to another version of the field equations that reveals a deep analogy to the equations of electrodynamics. Furthermore a method is developed that admits an unambiguous calculation of gauge-fixing conditions from a given gauge-breaking term. Besides the harmonic gauge, which can be reproduced by means of this method, new gauge-fixing conditions for local translations and local Lorentz transformations are obtained. These gauge-fixing techniques, as well as the symmetrization procedure, may equally be generalized to the case of nonvanishing torsion

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

record.content: <html><head><META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head><body><inisrecord> <action trn="US8320983" type="add" /> <record role="document" source-system="fibre" trn="US8320983" type="journal" rn="14800373"> <publication> <titles> <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">General relativity as a gauge theory of the Poincare group, the symmetric momentum tensor of both matter and gravity, and gauge-fixing conditions</title> </titles> <date value="1983-07-15" sici-chronology="19830715">15 Jul 1983</date> <country key="US">United States</country> <creators and-others="no"> <creator type="personal">Grensing, D.</creator> <creator type="personal">Grensing, G.</creator> <creator type="affiliation">Universitat Kiel, Fachbereich Physik, D-2300 Kiel, West Germany</creator> </creators> <availability inis="no"> <contact>Bibliographic information available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:14800373</contact> </availability> <is-part-of> <journal> <titles> <title type="primary">Physical Review. D, Particles Fields</title> <title type="abbreviated">Phys. Rev., D</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0556-2821</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 28(2) p. 286-296.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1100" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02989" assignment="indexer">electrodynamics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03899" assignment="indexer">gauge invariance</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05602" assignment="indexer">lorentz transformations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="indexer">metrics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="07663" assignment="indexer">poincare groups</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09368" assignment="indexer">spin</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="00410" assignment="upposted">angular momentum</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="04834" assignment="upposted">invariance principles</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05490" assignment="upposted">lie groups</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="07197" assignment="upposted">particle properties</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09721" assignment="upposted">symmetry groups</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">It is shown that a consistent gauging of the Poincare group is capable of including Einstein's general relativity. This statement holds for matter particles of arbitrary spin, provided the nontrivial part of the vierbein is taken as the fundamental gravitational field, thus giving rise to a known modification of the original theory. Since the gauge approach implies that gravitation is an ordinary field theory over flat space, the standard prescriptions for calculating the asymmetric momentum tensor of both matter and gravitation are available. Applying Belinfante's flat-space symmetrization procedure to the latter, we prove that the symmetrization of the asymmetric matter tensor just gives the dynamically defined symmetric matter tensor, whereas the symmetrization of the asymmetric gravitational momentum tensor leads to another version of the field equations that reveals a deep analogy to the equations of electrodynamics. Furthermore a method is developed that admits an unambiguous calculation of gauge-fixing conditions from a given gauge-breaking term. Besides the harmonic gauge, which can be reproduced by means of this method, new gauge-fixing conditions for local translations and local Lorentz transformations are obtained. These gauge-fixing techniques, as well as the symmetrization procedure, may equally be generalized to the case of nonvanishing torsion</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.content: Neobkhodima li ''obshchaya otnositel'nost''' dlya ehjnshejnovskoj teorii gravitatsii

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Astrophysics, quanta and relativity theory

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Karrelli, A.; Meller, K.; Bondi, G. (eds.) (and others); 42-52; 1982; 42-52; Mir; Moscow; 7 refs.; translation from Italian.

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CLASSICAL MECHANICS; CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MECHANICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Main principles of relativity and gravitation theories are deeply analyzed. Problems of boundaries of applicability for these theories and possible ways of their change and generalization are discussed. It is shown that the notion of general relativity does not introduce any post-newton physics - it only deals with coordinate transformations. It is supposed that ''general relativity'' is a physically senseless phrase which can be considered only as a historical remainder of an interesting philosophic discourse. The paper reveals that there exists appropriate physical substantiation of the Einstein gravitation theory not including a physically senseless concept of general relativity and promoting its fundamental relations with the experiment

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On pseudoparticle solutions in the Poincare gauge theory of gravity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN-MAXWELL EQUATIONS; EUCLIDEAN SPACE; FEYNMAN PATH INTEGRAL; INSTANTONS; METRICS; POINCARE GROUPS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; RIEMANN SPACE; TORSION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTEGRALS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUASI PARTICLES; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The dynamical structure of the Poincare gauge field theory coupled to matter fields and some of its implications for a quantum theory of gravity are investigated. Essentially, the method of Belavin et al. for generating instanton solutions in Yang-Mills theory is transferred to the gravitational gauge model. The results are as follows: For configurations obeying a modified double duality Ansatz for the curvature the metrical background is determined by Einstein-type field equations coupled almost canonically to the stress-energy content of external fields. Exact electrovac solutions with non-trivial torsion are derived from the duality Ansatz. In a Euclidean space-time the corresponding pseudoparticle solutions are expected to play a dominant role in the quantization of gravity via Feynman's method of path integrals. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A class of inhomogeneous Goedel-type solutions of Einstein's field equations is studied. The source of the geometries is a fluid with heat flow plus a scalar field. The thermodynamic properties of one specific solution are discussed. (Author)

meta.content: January 1985

meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: As a sequel to the previous paper dealing with analytical solutions of the Einstein equations with a cosmological constant Λ in the (1 + 1 + 2)-dimension, we studies analogous solutions in the (1 + n1 + n2)-dimension with the metric tensor g sub(MN) = (1, f2(t)gsub(mn), h2(t) γsub(ab)). It is qualitatively shown that the asymptotic forms of f(t) and h(t) when Λ > 0 will be exponentially increasing, while f(t) and h(t) when Λ < 0 take oscillatory forms. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1984

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: General exact solutions of Einstein equations for static perfect fluids with spherical symmetry

meta.name: Country
meta.content: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The gravitational field equations for a spherical symmetric perfect fluid are completely solved. The general analytical solution obtained depends on an arbitrary function of the radial coordinate. As an illustration example of the proposed procedure the exterior Schwarzschild solution is regained. (author)

meta.content: January 1985

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Vlasov, A.A.; Logunov, A.A.; Mestvirishvili, M.A. (Institute of High Energy Physics, Serpukhov)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Theory of gravitation based on minkowski space and the principle of geometrization

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Theoretical and Mathematical Physics; v. 61(3) p. 1167-1169; ISSN 0040-5779; CODEN TMPHA; Jun 1985; Cover-to-cover translation of Teoreticheskaya i Matematicheskaya Fizika (USSR).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GEOMETRY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; HILBERT SPACE; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; METRICS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BANACH SPACE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MATHEMATICS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SPACE; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The authors construct a theory of graviation on the basis of Minkowski space and the principle of geometrization. In it, the first six equations are Hilbert-Einstein equations, while the remaining four field equations are universal covariant harmonicity conditions. In contrast to the general theory of relativity, there are rigorous conservation laws for the energy, momentum, and angular momentum of a closed system. In the theory, only a ''flat'' universe is possible, and therefore the matter density must be equal to the critical density

meta.content: January 1985
