meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Azuma, Takahiro (Dokkyo Univ., Soka, Saitama (Japan)); Wada, Sumio.

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Classification of spatially flat cosmological solutions in the presence of the cosmological constant and backreaction of conformally invariant quantum fields

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 75(4) p. 845-861; ISSN 0033-068X; CODEN PTPKA; Apr 1986

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; CONTRACTION; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; EXPANSION; FLUCTUATIONS; POTENTIALS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SINGULARITY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; VARIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We find all the spatially flat Robertson-Walker type solutions of Einstein's equations with the cosmological constant and quantum fluctuations of conformally invariant matter fields, which include effects of the conformal anomaly. We show that the relevant back-reaction equation is interpreted as an equation of motion for a classical one-dimensional potential problem with (anti-) dissipation. By considering the potential form, we can easily classify all the solutions and understand their qualitative behaviour, such as monotonic expansion (contraction), oscillation, contraction followed by expansion. Only two kinds of asymptotic behaviour are allowed, both in the past and in the future. They are (1) exponential expansion or contraction (asymptotically de Sitter) and (2) singularity (zero or infinity of the scale factor) at a finite cosmic time. Stability of de Sitter solutions (singular solutions) is also discussed. The Minkowski solution in the case of the vanishing cosmological constant is shown to be unstable, irrespectively of the sign of a parameter in the equation. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Waugh, B.; Lake, K. (Department of Physics, Queen's University at Kingston, Kingston, Ontario, Canada K7L 3N6)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Double-null coordinates for the Vaidya metric

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 34(10) p. 2978-2984; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Nov 1986

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EIKONAL APPROXIMATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY; TENSOR FORCES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Einstein's equations with spherical symmetry are formulated in double-null coordinates, and the high-frequency approximation to a unidirectional radial flow of unpolarized radiation (the Vaidya metric) is studied in detail. For this case the Einstein equations reduce to a single first-order nonlinear partial differential equation. Integration of this equation introduces an arbitrary function (of one null variable) which must be chosen so as to regularize the metric across horizons. Although the problem is, in general, not analytically solvable, we are able to extend the class of known analytic solutions from the constant-mass case (Kruskal-Szekeres metric) to linear and exponential mass functions. In the linear case we give the first explicit regular covering of a spacetime with a naked shell-focusing singularity

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: AXIAL SYMMETRY; EIGENVALUES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; SCALAR FIELDS; STABILITY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The solution of Einstein equations for static spherically-symmetric massless scalar field is obtained. The stability of static massless scalar field of the point source is investigated. It has been found that the field is unstable at small and stable at sufficiently great relations of source scalar charge to its mass. The existence of dimensionless number limiting the stability region of the considered field is proved

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This book contains 117 workshop papers presented at the third Marcel Grossman Meeting on General Relativity. The papers are divided into 16 sections including: classical problem in gravitation; alternative approaches to gravitational theory; gravitational radiation and perturbation problems; exact solutions of Einstein's equations; numerical relativity; supersymmetry and supergravity; quantum gravity; quantum field theory in curved space-time; collapse objects; inhomogeneities in the Universe; GUT and cosmology; theories of the early Universe; gravitational wave experiments; gravitational wave antenna; transducers for gravitational wave antennas; gravitational experiments. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ALGEBRAIC CURRENTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; METRICS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CURRENTS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Based on the Belinskil-Zakharov (BZ) formulation of the vacuum Einstein equation with the metric gsub(ab) depending only on two coordinates, the related infinitely conserved currents are discussed. It is shown that there appears a set of nonlocal conservation currents which can be regarded as a parametric Noether current which arises from 'H-transformation'. By combining the transformation with BZ's L-A pair the GxC(t) algebraic structure in BZ's gravitational formulation is derived. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Isenberg, J. (California Univ., Berkeley (USA). Dept. of Mathematics); Moncrief, V. (Yale Univ., New Haven, CT (USA). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On cosmic censorship: do compact Cauchy horizons imply symmetry?

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 904 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 561-573; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN-MAXWELL EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; VECTOR FIELDS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The basic idea of Cosmic Censorship is that, in a physically reasonable spacetime, an observer should not encounter any naked singularities. The authors discuss some new results which provide strong support for one of the statements of Cosmic Censorship: Strong Cosmic Censorship says that the maximal spacetime development of a set of Cauchy data on a spacelike initial surface (evolved via the vacuum Einstein equations, the Einstein-Maxwell equations, or some other 'reasonable' set) will not be extendible across a Cauchy horizon. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The problem of motion in the Kaluza theory

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 903-909; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (A2140)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; MAXWELL EQUATIONS; METRICS; MOTION; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The authors deduce the Kaluza equation from the actions of the Kaluza field and the particle by virtue of the variational principle as well as the Lagrange multipliers method. They then prove that the laws of motion of the particle are consequences of the Kaluza equations. Finally, the problem of motion in the electromagnetic field on the Minkowskian space-time is dealt with by means of the Kaluza mechanism of the theory. (G.T.H.)

meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Gerlach, U.H. (Department of Mathematics, Ohio State University, Columbus, USA)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Gravitational radiation from perturbed astrophysical sources

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 963-967; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; METRICS; PERTURBATION THEORY; SPACE-TIME; SPHERICAL HARMONICS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; RADIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is remarkable how little is known of the exact nature of signals from some of the prime candidates for the emission of gravitational radiation. These candidates include realistic spherically symmetric collapsing or non-linearly pulsating or exploding astrophysical configurations suffering from slight asymmetries. The theory of their evolution is described by the Einstein field equations linearized around some given spherically symmetric astrophysical configuration. The author formulates perturbation theory which is not only aesthetically very appealing, but is so powerful that it can deal with any astrophysical perturbation problem. Perturbation theory is supported by three legs: spherical harmonics on S2; geometrical objects on M2 = M4/S2; and gauge invariants. All three are indispensible ingredients for perturbation theory. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BAECKLUND TRANSFORMATION; DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GEOMETRY; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICS; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The Einstein equations for gravitational fields in vacuum simplify considerably when two commuting isometries exist. In the case of two space-like Killing fields (e.g. cylindrical symmetry), and assuming orthogonal transitivity, the equations reduce to an equation which, is formally identical to the Ernst equation. The author discusses Baecklund transformations of the Ernst equation. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1983

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The stationary gravitational field of an infinite rod in Einstein's theory of gravitation with the harmonic condition is given. It becomes the result for the static case when the constant of integration related with rotation of the rod around its axis becomes zero. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.content: Geometrical meaning of Baecklund transformation for Ernst equation

meta.content: BAECKLUND TRANSFORMATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MATRICES; MINKOWSKI SPACE; RICCATI EQUATION; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; SPACE; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: An Einstein spacetime E admitting a two-parameter Abelian group G2 of isometries may be described covariantly on a two dimensional manifold S. From the two independent Killing vector fields that generate the group G2 a 2x2 matrix is obtained. For simplicity the authors stick to the assumption that both Killing vectors are spacelike, but the case that one of Killing vectors is timelike can be discussed similarly. So in this case the base space S is a 2-dimensional Minkowski space. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.content: N rank zero HKX transformations

meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1053-1057; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The author derives a new representation of an arbitrary number of rank zero HKX transformations acting on an arbitrary Weyl solution as seed metric and presents the resulting Ernst potential by means of determinants. He solves Yamazaki's equations and gives the full four dimensional metric of the corresponding stationary axisymmetric vacuum solution of Einstein's equations which is asymptotically flat up to an Ehlers transformation. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1983

meta.content: BAECKLUND TRANSFORMATION; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; BOUNDARY-VALUE PROBLEMS; DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; HARMONICS; LAPLACE EQUATION; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GEOMETRY; MATHEMATICS; OSCILLATIONS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: If M is a Riemannian manifold, i.e. the metric of M is positively definite, then the Euler equation of the energy integral is a system of nonlinear elliptic equations. If M is a Lorentzian manifold, then the Euler equation is a nonlinear hyperbolic system. The author discusses the problem of whether there exists a relationship between harmonic maps and the nonlinear elliptic equations. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.content: Page, D.N. (Pennsylvania State Univ., University Park (USA). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Approximate stress tensors near a black hole

meta.name: LeadTitle
meta.content: Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1189-1192; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GEODESICS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; WKB APPROXIMATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: One goal of quantum field theory in curved spacetime is to calculate the renormalized expectation value of the stress-energy tensor for certain quantum states in various geometries, such as the thermal Hartle-Hawking equilibrium state in the gravitational field of a Schwarzschild black hole. The Gaussian path-integral method of Bekenstein and Parker is used to give an explicit WKB approximation for the renormalized stress-energy tensor of a conformally invariant scalar field in a thermal state in any static metric which satisfies Einstein's equations. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1983

meta.content: Einsteins dream

meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; HADRONS; HISTORICAL ASPECTS; LEPTONS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM CHROMODYNAMICS; SPACE-TIME; SUPERGRAVITY; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This book discusses the following topics: the search for meaning; Einstein's dream; curved space; Einstein and warped space-time and extreme wraping; early unified field theories; star death; beyond the white dwarf; the early universe; the hadron, Lepton, and Radiation eras; the redshift controversy; other universes; the final fate of the universe; the missing mass; bounce; fate of the open universe; the world of particles and fields; Dirac's equation; Yukawa; gauge theory; quantum chromodynamics; supergravity and superstrings; twistors and heaven; and the new Einstein

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

and warped space-time and extreme wraping; early unified field theories; star death; beyond the white dwarf; the early universe; the hadron, Lepton, and Radiation eras; the redshift controversy; other universes; the final fate of the universe; the missing mass; bounce; fate of the open universe; the world of particles and fields; Dirac's equation; Yukawa; gauge theory; quantum chromodynamics; meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Alexander, M.; Bergmann, P.G. (Fordham Univ., New York, NY)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The gravitational field at spatial infinity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Foundations of Physics; v. 16(5) p. 445-454; ISSN 0015-9018; CODEN FNDPA; May 1986

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GEODESICS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LORENTZ TRANSFORMATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; QUANTIZATION; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY GROUPS; TENSORS; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This paper treats the formulation of the gravitational field variables and the equations obeyed by them at spatial infinity. The variables consist of a three-dimensional tensor and a scalar, which satisfy separate field equations, which in turn can be obtained from two distinct Lagrangians. Aside from Lorentz rotations, the symmetry operations include an Abelian gauge group and an Abelian Lie group, leading to a number of conservation laws and to differential indentities between the field equations

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Tangherlini, F.R. (College of the Holy Cross, Worcester, MA (USA). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Dimensionality of space and the pulsating universe

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Nuovo Cim., B; v. 91(2) p. 209-217; ISSN 0369-3554; CODEN NCIBA; 11 Feb 1986

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BOUND STATE; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; KINETIC ENERGY; MACH PRINCIPLE; METRICS; SPACE; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ENERGY; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; HYPOTHESIS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is shown that, when the dimensionality of the kinetic-energy term is increased in Einstein's field equations for the Friedmann-Robertson-Walker metric in n dimensions, in the absence of a pressure term, stable bound states of the Universe are only found for n =2, 3 and 4. With the further assumption that space is closed, together with a suitable application of Mach's principle, the cases n = 2, 4 can be excluded, so that one has a cosmological approach to deriving the three-dimensionality of space. A speculative way to resolve the ''short age'' problem of a Ω > 1 Universe is also described

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Christodoulou, D. (Syracuse Univ., NY (USA). Dept. of Mathematics; Syracuse Univ., NY (USA). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A mathematical theory of gravitational collapse

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Communications in Mathematical Physics; v. 109(4) p. 613-647; ISSN 0010-3616; CODEN CMPHA; Apr 1987; GRANT MCS-8201599; PHY-83-18350

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METRICS; REST MASS; SCALAR FIELDS; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; STAR EVOLUTION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MASS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We study the asymptotic behaviour, as the retarded time u tends to infinity, of the solutions of Einstein's equations in the spherically symmetric case with a massless scalar field as the material model. We prove that when the final Bondi mass M1 is different from zero, as u→∞, a black hole forms of mass M1 surrounded by vacuum. We find the rate of decay of the metric functions and the behaviour of the scalar field on the horizon. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Laguna-Castillo, P.; Matzner, R.A. (Texas Univ., Austin (USA). Center for Relativity; Texas Univ., Austin (USA). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Surfaces of discontinuity in five-dimensional Kaluza-Klein cosmologies

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Nuclear Physics. B; v. 282(3/4) p. 542-554; ISSN 0550-3213; CODEN NUPBB; 2 Mar 1987; GRANT CONACY 49104; PHY-84-04931

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BUBBLES; COSMIC DUST; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DELTA FUNCTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EQUATIONS OF STATE; EXPANSION; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; METRICS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; THERMAL RADIATION; UNIVERSE; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DUSTS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RADIATIONS; TENSORS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Based on Israel's work on surface layers in general relativity, we study a 4-dimensional Robertson-Walker space-time as a singular hypersurface of discontinuity Σ embedded in a matter-free 5-dimensional Kaluza-Klein cosmology with non-vanishing cosmological constant. As in the case of vacuum bubbles in phase transitions, the 4-dimensional hypersurface Σ has contributions from a jump discontinuity and a δ-function singularity in the cosmological constant and the 5-dimensional stress-energy tensor, respectively. Since under this model our observable 4-dimensional space-time is considered to be the surface layer Σ, this identification yields dynamic evolution of our observable spatial sector in the fifth dimension due to the singular nature of Σ. An effective radiation content is typically present in the hypersurface due to the cosmological constant in the embedding and the evolution of the internal dimension. Even for the case when the effective radiation is continuous across Σ, this hypersurface will still be singular so long as there is a δ-function singularity in the 5-dimensional stress-energy tensor there. It is possible then to rewrite the projected 5-dimensional Einstein equations on the surface layer in a way similar to the 4-dimensional Einstein equations for a Robertson-Walker cosmology with independently specifiable matter sources. The freedom to specify the equation of state on the hypersurface allows in this sense a 4-dimensional expansion behavior, as measured by an observer on Σ, independent of the behavior of the fifth dimension. (orig.)

meta.name: Abstract1
meta.content: 4-dimensional expansion behavior, as measured by an observer on Σ, independent of the behavior of the fifth dimension. (orig.)

meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A new class of exact spatially inhomogeneous cosmological solutions of the Einstein field equations is presented in which the source of the gravitational field is an irrotational fluid with heat flow. The solutions can be considered as generalisations of a subclass of the Szekeres solutions. In the most general case the fluid has non-zero pressure and heat flow and the cosmological constant is also non-zero. A comprehensive analysis of the initial singularity structure and the evolution in time of a subclass of the solutions is given as well as some discussion of the thermodynamic behaviour of the models. (author)

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The conditions for residual supersymmetry in compactified ten-dimensional supergravity theories are investigated, including the effect of a non-constant ''warp factor''. The analyis is based on on-shell transformation on laws which implies that certain linear combinations of classical field equations must be satisfied. The conditions for supersymmetry are, in general not very restrictive. When, in addition, one assumes the validity of Bianchi identifiers, two independent contractions of the Einstein equation are implied. These equations exclude d=4 de Sitter space; for compactifications to d=4 Minkowski space they only allow purely metric Ricci-flat field configurations with constant warp factor. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The author presents a series of lectures intended for students familiar with the methods used in many developments of general relativity, cosmology and supergravity. First, he deals with geometry before gravity; manifolds, tensors, spinors and their derivatives are defined. The rules of Cartan's exterior differential calculus are established. Basic formulas of Riemannian geometry are proved with the method of the moving frame (veilbein). Some aspects of the de Rham cohomology are lightly touched on; the physical meaning of the curvature tensor which leads to the Einstein equations is analyzed; Weyl's and Palitini's variational principle are introduced and compared; the extension of first integrals for field equations on curved space is discussed; and finally, a brief description of homogeneous cosmologies, in particular the anti-de Sitter space, is given

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MECHANICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The dissertation investigates the effect of quantum processes on specific Kaluza-Klein models. The cosmologies of these models are determined by solving Einstein's field equations. The quantum effects are shown to be important in determining not only the size of the extra dimension, and the cosmologies these models must follow, but also the stability of these cosmologies to small variations in the size of the extra dimensions. The effect a dynamical extra dimension would have on the production of massive particles and photons is discussed, and shown to lead to drastic consequences for the energy density of our universe. (UK)

meta.content: January 1985

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is known that the asymptotic states of a large class of spatially homogeneous cosmological models, near the big bang and at late times, are described by exact self-similar solutions. With this as motivation, all spatially homogeneous solutions of the Einstein field equations are found, which have an orthogonal perfect fluid as source, or are vacuum, and admit a similarity group H4 which acts transitively on spacetime. (author)

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Einstein's field equations are solved for the case of the eleven-dimensional vacuum spacetime which is the product R x Bianchi V x T7, where T7 is a seven-dimensional torus. Among all possible solutions, the authors identify those in which the macroscopic space expands and the microscopic space contracts to a finite size. The solutions with this property are 'typical' within the considered class. They implement the idea of a purely dynamical dimensional reduction. (author)

Obserwatorium Astronomiczne</creator> </creators> <availability inis="no"> <contact>Bibliographic information available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:18048283</contact> </availability> <is-part-of> <journal> <titles> <title type="primary">Classical and Quantum Gravity</title> <title type="abbreviated">Class. Quantum Gravity</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0264-9381</identifier> <identifier type="coden">CQGRD</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 3(6) p. 1199-1205.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1120" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="00389" assignment="indexer">analytical solution</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="23384" assignment="indexer">compactification</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02277" assignment="indexer">cosmological models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02278" assignment="indexer">cosmology</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="22149" assignment="indexer">kaluza-klein theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="13592" assignment="indexer">many-dimensional calculations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09719" assignment="indexer">symmetry</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="10231" assignment="indexer">time dependence</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="18029" assignment="upposted">unified-field theories</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Einstein's field equations are solved for the case of the eleven-dimensional vacuum spacetime which is the product R x Bianchi V x T<sup>7</sup>, where T<sup>7</sup> is a seven-dimensional torus. Among all possible solutions, the authors identify those in which the macroscopic space expands and the microscopic space contracts to a finite size. The solutions with this property are 'typical' within the considered class. They implement the idea of a purely dynamical dimensional reduction. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="GB">United Kingdom</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Ribeiro, M.B.; Sanyal, A.K. (Observatorio Nacional, CEP 20921, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Bianchi VI0 viscous fluid cosmology with magnetic field

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(3) p. 657-660; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Mar 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DISSIPATION FACTOR; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EQUATIONS OF STATE; EXPANSION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MAGNETIC FIELDS; NEUTRINOS; SINGULARITY; VISCOSITY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LEPTONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A spatially homogeneous Bianchi type VI0 model containing a viscous fluid in the presence of an axial magnetic field has been studied. A barotropic equation of state together with a pair of linear relations among the square root of matter density, shear scalar, and expansion scalar have been assumed. Solutions are obtained in the presence of a magnetic field, only in two special cases, which are comparatively easy. The complete solutions for this model in the absence of a magnetic field are also obtained. The presence of a magnetic field in the former case, however, does not in effect cause any major modification in the fundamental nature of the initial singularity of the expanding model

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1987

meta.content: A radiating Kerr-Newman solution

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN-MAXWELL EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; KERR METRIC; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A non-static exact solution of Einstein's equations corresponding to a field of flowing null radiation plus an electromagnetic field is presented. The geometry of the solution is described by the Kerr-Schild metric. The solution admits a shear-free, geodetic null congruence. It has the symmetry of the Kerr-Newman solution and when a certain parameter is put equal to zero the solution becomes static and reduces to the Kerr-Newman solution. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1530); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; DYNAMICS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; MASS; SCALARS; STAR EVOLUTION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MECHANICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A mathematical study of the dynamics of gravitational collapse and the formation of black holes is presented. The global initial value problems for Einstein's equations in the spherically symmetric case with a massless scalar field, and for arbitrarily large initial data are examined. The required equations and theorems for the solution of the problem are presented. The asymptotic behavior of the global generalized solutions as the retarded time approaches infinity is studied. It is shown that when the final Bondi mass is different from zero, as the retarded time approaches infinity, a black hole forms surrounded by a vacuum

meta.content: January 1986

meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTERACTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MONOPOLES; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A dissertation is presented on magnetic monopoles and relativistic cosmological models. The maximum number density of monopoles in various astrophysical scenarios was investigated along with: the monopole flux in the galaxy, the allowed monopole abundance, and the formation of stable monopole orbits. Limits on the mass and lifetime of monopolonium were calculated. Boltzmann's equation was used to calculate the monopole abundance in a magnetic axisymmetric Bianchi I cosmological model, and a solution was found describing an axisymmetric Bianchi I magnetic cosmology with monopoles. New inhomogeneous solutions to Einstein's equations were found. Finally, stability and inflation in Kaluza-Klein cosmologies in d + D + 1 dimensions was studied. (UK)

assignment="upposted">particle interactions</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="07782" assignment="upposted">postulated particles</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="18029" assignment="upposted">unified-field theories</descriptor> </descriptors> <qualifiers> <qualifier key="thesis-dissertation">Thesis/Dissertation</qualifier> </qualifiers> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">A dissertation is presented on magnetic monopoles and relativistic cosmological models. The maximum number density of monopoles in various astrophysical scenarios was investigated along with: the monopole flux in the galaxy, the allowed monopole abundance, and the formation of stable monopole orbits. Limits on the mass and lifetime of monopolonium were calculated. Boltzmann's equation was used to calculate the monopole abundance in a magnetic axisymmetric Bianchi I cosmological model, and a solution was found describing an axisymmetric Bianchi I magnetic cosmology with monopoles. New inhomogeneous solutions to Einstein's equations were found. Finally, stability and inflation in Kaluza-Klein cosmologies in d + D + 1 dimensions was studied. (UK)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="GB">United Kingdom</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A convenient framework is set up for constructing cylindrically symmetric solutions of the Einstein and the Einstein-Maxwell equations, and it is shown how a Hamiltonian density can be defined for space-times with cylindrical symmetry. Solutions are obtained that represent stationary monochromatic waves and satisfy all the requisite conditions of regularity. The case when the gravitational field is coupled with a perfect fluid in which the energy density is equal to the pressure is also briefly considered. (author)

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Gerlach, U.H.; Scott, J.F. (Department of Mathematics, Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio 43210)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Metric elasticity in a collapsing star: Gravitational radiation coupled to torsional motion

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 34(12) p. 3638-3649; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Dec 1986

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1530); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; NEUTRINOS; PERTURBATION THEORY; SPACE-TIME; STARS; TORSION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LEPTONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Torsional oscillatory matter motion as well as differential rotation couple via the linearized Einstein field equations to the gravitational degrees of freedom. For an arbitrary spherically symmetric background, such as that of a wildly pulsating or a catastrophically collapsing star, we exhibit (a) the strain tensor and (b) the corresponding stress-energy tensor. It is found that in the star there are two elasticity tensors. One expresses the familiar elasticity of matter, the other expresses the elasticity of the geometry. This metric elasticity is responsible for coupling the gravitational and matter degrees of freedom. The two coupled scalar wave equations for these degrees of freedom are exhibited. Also exhibited are their characteristics as well as the junction conditions for their solutions across any spherical surface of discontinuity

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; COSMIC RADIATION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY SPECTRA; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; QUANTIZATION; QUANTUM MECHANICS; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; IONIZING RADIATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; RADIATIONS; SPECTRA

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This paper presents exact solutions to the Einstein field equations which describe a Schwarzschild black hole with shells of matter (a null fluid) representing radiation. A description of the models is presented in the hope of increasing the understanding of the Hawking effect; some of the back-reaction effects are invorporated the model. The results presented are classical in nature and their relevance to the Hawking temperature remains to be demonstrated

meta.content: Numerical investigations of cosmic censorship on T3 x R

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CAUCHY PROBLEM; COMPUTER CODES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BOUNDARY-VALUE PROBLEMS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A computer program is developed which solves the full nonlinear Einstein equations with one Killing field on a 3-torus as a Cauchy problem. Space times are generated in a fully constrained manner with only the true degrees of freedom being propagated. The two gravitational degrees of freedom are described by scalar fields defined in terms of the killing vector. The remaining metric quantities are found by imposing the constant mean curvature gauge condition and solving the constraints explicitly during the evolution of the space time. The ultimate aim of the project is to generate evidence for or against certain conjectures of classical relativity based on studies of space times with greater symmetry. Such a program makes possible the experimental determination of the generic behavior of solutions to the field equations

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.content: Spacetimes with cosmological constant and a conformal Killing field have constant curvature

meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.content: Journal article

meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CONFORMAL GROUPS; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; DE SITTER GROUP; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; LIE GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The assumption that a spacetime possesses a conformal Killing field which is not a Killing field can be very restrictive. The authors examine the effect of this assumption on vacuum solutions of Einstein's equation with cosmological constant. It is shown that all such solutions have constant curvature and are therefore either de Sitter spacetimes or anti-de Sitter spacetimes, depending on the sign of the cosmological constant. (author)

meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is shown that in an algebraically special space-time that admits a congruence of null strings, the Yang--Mills equations with sources reduce to a pair of nonlinear first-order differential equations for two matrices, provided that the gauge field is aligned with the congruence. In the case where the current is tangent to the null strings, the gauge field is determined by a matrix potential that has to satisfy a second-order differential equation with quadratic nonlinearities. As an example of this case, the Yang--Mills--Weyl equations are reduced, assuming that the multiplet of Weyl neutrino fields are also aligned with the congruence, and a reduced form of the Einstein--Yang--Mills--Weyl equations is also given

meta.content: January 1987

meta.content: Gravity from strings

meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.content: AMPLITUDES; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; INTERACTIONS; MANY-BODY PROBLEM; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METRICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE MODELS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RADIATIONS; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We obtain the Einstein action plus quadratic curvature corrections generated by closed bosonic, heterotic and supersymmetric strings by matching the four-graviton amplitude (to first order in the slope parameter and fourth power of momenta) with an effective local gravitational action. The resulting corrections are first shown to be of the Gauss-Bonnet form. It is then noted that, by the very nature of the slope expansion, the field-redefinition theorem applies. Consequently, only the curvature-squared term is determined, while squares of its contractions are explicitly seen not to contribute. This latter property has a generalization to all orders which implies that the effective gravitational action is unavoidably ghost-free. The properties of solutions to these corrected theories are then examined. First neglecting dilatons, we find the explicit 'Schwarzschild' metrics. Both asymptotically flat and de Sitter solutions are present. The latter are however shown to be unstable. The former have horizons and singularities which are respectively smaller and less violent than in Einstein gravity; the correct sign of the slope parameter also ensures absence of naked singularities. When dilatons are included, the cosmological vacua are gratifyingly excluded. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1987

meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; WAVE EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The field equations for the class of perfect fluid space-times with local rotational symmetry which the authors had earlier shown the Dirac equation separates are studied. For the vacuum and dust cases all possible solutions are exhibited. Other solutions correspond to radiation, a stiff fluid, and a fluid with negative pressure

meta.content: January 1987

meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATION; GROUP THEORY; METRICS; RICCI TENSOR; SPACE-TIME; TORSION; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The Einstein-invariant gravitation gauge theory (EGT) with localization of the motion group of uniform static Einstein Universe is considered. Taking account of cosmologic member EGT exact solutions in the form of nonsingular uniform isotropic cosmological models providing for both metrics and torsion regularity are obtained. EGT is shown to comply with the Newton gravitation theory and that of tetrad gravitation in absolute parallelism space

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A new self-similar solution of the Einstein field equations is presented. In the new space-time, the density is zero at time zero and follows an inverse square law for large t. The new solution may have interesting astrophysical applications since it has the same reference lengths as that of the Friedmann universe

meta.content: January 1987

The new solution may have interesting astrophysical applications since it has the same reference lengths as that of the Friedmann universe</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Accioly, A.J.; Goncalves, A.T. (Instituto de Fisica, Universidade de Sao Paulo, Caixa Postal 20516, 01498-Sao Paulo, Brazil)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Homogeneous space-times of Goedel-type in higher-derivative gravity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(7) p. 1547-1552; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Jul 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; METRICS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; ROTATION; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A general theorem concerning any Goedel-type solution of higher-derivative gravity field equations, which may be produced by any reasonable physical source with a constant energy-momentum tensor, is analyzed. The resulting class of metrics depends on two parameters, one of which is related to the vorticity. A general class of solutions of Goedel-type space-time-homogeneous universes in the context of the higher-derivative theory is exhibited. This is the most general higher-derivative solution of such type of metric and includes all known solutions of Einstein's equations related to these geometries as a special case. A number of completely causal rotating models is also obtained. Some of them present the interesting feature of having no analogs in the framework of general relativity

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Static solutions and equilibrium distributions of a gravitating fluid in general relativity. I - Plane symmetry

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Soviet Astronomy; v. 30 p. 142-145; ISSN 0038-5301; CODEN SAAJA; Apr 1986; Cover-to-cover translation of Astronomicheskij Zhurnal (USSR).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGY; DENSITY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The general relativity of static V4 gravitational fields with planar symmetry is examined, along with the associated equilibrium distributions of a gravitating fluid for relativistic polytropic state equations. An exact static interior solution derived for the Einstein equations is shown to contain a singular Taub-Kasner vacuum source with a negative bare gravitational mass on the Z = 0 plane, on which the entire distribution of gravitating matter halts. The results demonstrate that General Relativity has no analog in Newtonian models of a planar, symmetric, equilibrium layer of a gravitating fluid. 19 references

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We propose that the natural lagrangian density for a Kaluza-Klein theory in D=2N+2 and 2N+3 dimensions, with an internal homogeneous space G/H, is the Euler-Poincare density in 2N dimensions. When reduced to spacetime such an action is free from the cosmological terms and it contains the Einstein-Yang-Mills action aswell as additional interactions involving gauge fields and gravity. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICS; SYMMETRY GROUPS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Recent developments in higher-dimensional unified field theories have led to a great deal of interest in compact spaces admitting Einstein Metrics. Almost all the physics literature on such spaces has been concerned with the very atypical case in which the space is homogeneous. In the paper, the authors present a very simple construction of a wide class of inhomogeneous compact Einstein spaces with positive Ricci curvature, which arise as certain 2-sphere bundles over an arbitrary Einstein-Kaehler base space of positive Ricci curvature. Solutions on complete non-compact manifolds also exist, with negative or zero Ricci curvature. (author)

meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SYMMETRY; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Exact plane wave solutions of d=10, N=1 Einstein-Yang-Mills supergravity theory are presented and their possible modifications in superstring effective theories are examined. It is found that the solutions are not affected by any of the known heterotic string corrections. It is argued that plane waves satisfy the effective field equations of the heterotic string theory in all powers of the string tension parameter α', possibly after including a totally antisymmetric torsion field and reinterpreting the constants. Similar remarks also apply for type I superstrings. Further properties of the solutions are discussed. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1987

assignment="upposted">quantum field theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09719" assignment="upposted">symmetry</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="18029" assignment="upposted">unified-field theories</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Exact plane wave solutions of d=10, N=1 Einstein-Yang-Mills supergravity theory are presented and their possible modifications in superstring effective theories are examined. It is found that the solutions are not affected by any of the known heterotic string corrections. It is argued that plane waves satisfy the effective field equations of the heterotic string theory in all powers of the string tension parameter α', possibly after including a totally antisymmetric torsion field and reinterpreting the constants. Similar remarks also apply for type I superstrings. Further properties of the solutions are discussed. (orig.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="NL">Netherlands</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is shown that Einstein's equations are always linearization stable around any finite region of space-time. Let (Ω,g0/sub a//sub b/ ) be any region of space-time, admitting a compact Cauchy surface with nonempty smooth boundary, and with g0/sub a//sub b/ a sufficiently smooth solution of the vacuum Einstein equation. It is shown that for any solution g1/sub a//sub b/ of the linearized equation and any open region Uis contained inΩ, there exists a smooth one-parameter family g/sup λ//sub a//sub b/ of solutions on U such that (g/sup λ//sub a//sub b/chemical bond/sub λ//sub //sub = /0 = g0/sub a//sub b/ ) chemical bond/sub U/ and ((d/dλ)g/sup λ//sub a//sub b/ = g1/sub a//sub b/ )chemical bond/sub U/

meta.content: Kinky torsion in a Poincare gauge model of gravity coupled to a massless scalar field

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; CONFIGURATION; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE MODELS; POTENTIALS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS; WAVE EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: For the quadratic Poincare gauge theory coupled to a massless scalar field (''Higgs field'') we study spherically symmetric solutions with duality properties of the Riemann-Cartan curvature. We find an exact solution with a localized scalar field and a torsion kink both residing in an open einsteinian microcosmos. Via a new dynamical mechanism, the asymptotically constant torsion compensates the bare ''cosmological'' constant. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Kolassis, C.A.; Santos, N.O. (Paris-6 Univ., 75 (France). Inst. Henri Poincare)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Spacetimes with a preferred null direction and a two-dimensional group of isometries: the null dust case

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 4(3) p. 599-618; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 May 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; AXIAL SYMMETRY; DUSTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; METRICS; ROTATION; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The authors consider spacetimes of general relativity admitting a preferred null direction lsup(μ) and a two-dimensional Abelian group of isometries G2. A null tetrad formulation of the Killing equations is given, as well as a classification of G2 according to the orientation of lsup(μ) with respect to the group transitivity surfaces. Two theorems concerning the action of the isometry group on lsup(μ) are presented: the first one deals with spacetimes admitting at least one Killing vector, while the second one deals with spacetimes admitting a G2. The Einstein field equations with a shear-free and diverging null dust source are integrated under certain assumptions. By switching off the null dust, the underlying vacuum metrics are obtained which generalise some of the diverging Petrov type D vacuum metrics found by previous workers. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTEGRALS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SYMMETRY GROUPS; U GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We show that the Callan et al. effective equations of motion for the bosonic closed string in a non-trivial background may not be derived only from the bosonic part of the N=1 supergravity action of Manton and Chapline, but also from just a general conformally invariant theory of gravity. In our scheme the invariance under gauge transformations of the antisymmetric tensor field turns out to be a consequence of the metricity condition. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear

xml:lang="en">We show that the Callan et al. effective equations of motion for the bosonic closed string in a non-trivial background may not be derived only from the bosonic part of the N=1 supergravity action of Manton and Chapline, but also from just a general conformally invariant theory of gravity. In our scheme the invariance under gauge transformations of the antisymmetric tensor field turns out to be a consequence of the metricity condition. (orig.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="DE">Germany</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; BOSONS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ELECTRODYNAMICS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; INTERACTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RADIATIONS; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS; TRANSFORMATIONS; U GROUPS; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Electric charges and free electromagnetic waves are supposed to be described locally with the same wave differential equation. It is only the topology that is considered to be different. The calculated nonlocal U(2) individuals are characterized by polynomials that belong neither to the classical nor to the Szegoe polynomials. The construction of the polynomial solution in component form, their orthogonality over singular measures, the relationships to the Jacobi polynomials, Rodriguez formulas, product decomposition, asymptotic formulas, and completeness are presented in some detail. The possibility is discussed of whether this highly nonlocal model for electric charges can have a physical significance. This work is intended to be a first step for the realization of an old idea of Einstein's (and also commented on by Dirac) to start with the electric charge, not with the Planck constant, as the primary concept for quantum theory

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Letelier, P.S.; Verdaguer, E. (Departamento de Fisica Universidade de Brasilia, 70910 Brasilia, Brazil)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Anisotropic fluid with SU(2)-type structure in general relativity: A model of localized matter

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(10) p. 2431-2436; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Oct 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ANISOTROPY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETISM; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; SU-2 GROUPS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; MAGNETISM; SU GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A model of anisotropic fluid with three perfect fluid components in interaction is studied. Each fluid component obeys the stiff matter equation of state and is irrotational. The interaction is chosen to reproduce an integrable system of equations similar to the one associated to self-dual SU(2) gauge fields. An extension of the Belinsky--Zakharov version of the inverse scattering transform is presented and used to find soliton solutions to the coupled Einstein equations. A particular class of solutions that can be interpreted as lumps of matter propagating in empty space-time is examined

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Ranganathan, D. (Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, New Delhi, 110 029, India)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Geometric interpretation for the Dirac field in curved space

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(10) p. 2437-2439; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Oct 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COMMUTATION RELATIONS; DIRAC APPROXIMATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; SCALE INVARIANCE; SPINORS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES; VECTOR FIELDS; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The imposition of the condition of length invariance on a Weyl manifold that does not lead uniquely to general relativity is shown. Rather, in this limit, the Weyl vector field can be interpreted as a Dirac current. The action is also the same as the Einstein Dirac one, if and only if, the spinor field is anticommuting. The allowed interactions are greatly restricted. They are only minimal gauge couplings and Yukawa interactions with a scalar field transforming according to the rules of Utiyama [Prog. Theor. Phys. 53, 565 (1975)]

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Wang Youtang (International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)); He Zhixian (Shanghai Jiaotong Univ., Shanghai (China). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: A set of exact two soliton wave solutions to Einstein field equations

meta.name: Country
meta.content: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2110)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; SINGULARITY; SOLITONS; WAVE FUNCTIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; QUASI PARTICLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A set of exact solutions of Einstein equations in vacuum is obtained. Taking this set of solutions as seed solutions and making use of the Belinsky-Zakharov generation technique a set of generated solutions is constructed. Both set of exact solutions and a set of generated solutions describe two solition waves, which propagate in opposite directions and collide with each other, and then recover their original shapes. The singularities of the two set of solutions are analyzed. The relationship between our solutions and other solutions is also discussed. (author). 11 refs, 4 figs

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1991

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Tapia, V.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Motion in fourth-rank gravity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2110)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGY; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GEODESICS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Recently we have explored the consequences of describing the metric properties of our universe through a quartic line element. In this geometry the natural object is a fourth-rank metric, i.e., a tensor with four indices. Based on this geometry we constructed a simple field theory for the gravitational field. The field equations coincide with the Einstein field equations in the vacuum case. This fact, however, does not guarantee the observational equivalence of both theories since one must still verify that, as a consequence of the field equations, test particles move along geodesics. This letter is aimed at establishing this result. (author). 7 refs

meta.content: January 1992

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is shown that from the first principles of General Relativity it follows that there exists a new type of interactions which are tightly connected with the gravitational interactions. New particles representing a new form of interactions do not interact electromagnetically, strongly and weakly with the known elementary particles. Physics of the new particles is defined by the Planck scales. (author.). 9 refs

meta.content: January 1993

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: It is a short review of today's gauge gravity theories and their relations with Einstein General Relativity. The conceptions of construction of the gauge gravity theories with higher derivatives are analyzed. GR is regarded as the gauge gravity theory corresponding to the choice of G∞4 as the local gauge symmetry group and the symmetrical tensor of rank two gμν as the field variable. Using the mathematical technique, single for all fundamental interactions (namely variational formalism for infinite Lie groups), we can obtain Einstein's theory as the gauge theory without any changes. All other gauge approaches lead to non-Einstein theories of gravity. But above-mentioned mathematical technique permits us to construct the gauge gravity theory of higher order (for instance SO (3,1)-gravity) so that all vacuum solutions of Einstein equations are the solutions of the SO (3,1)-gravity theory. The structure of equations of SO(3,1)-gravity becomes analogous to Weeler-Misner geometrodynamics one

meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; PHYSICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Within the framework of Einstein—Cartan theory, we obtain a general condition leading to singularity and inflation for all Bianchi cosmological models. If the spin energy is smaller than anisotropic energy density (i.e. S2 − σ2 ≤ 0), the Universe can not avoid singularity. If S2-σ2 > -(ρv)/s (ρv is vacuum energy density), the Universe can undergo an inflation phase. Examples of Bianchi type-K, I and V cosmological models are discussed. (geophysics, astronomy, and astrophysics)

meta.content: January 2011

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Einstein field equations with variable gravitational and cosmological constants are considered in the presence of a perfect fluid for a Bianchi type-I universe by assuming that the cosmological term is proportional to the Hubble parameter. The variation law for vacuum density was recently proposed by Schützhold on the basis of quantum field estimation in a curved expanding background. The cosmological term tends asymptotically to a genuine cosmological constant and the model tends to a de Sitter universe. We obtain that the present universe is accelerating with a large fraction of cosmological density in the form of a cosmological term

flow</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09721" assignment="upposted">symmetry groups</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Einstein field equations with variable gravitational and cosmological constants are considered in the presence of a perfect fluid for a Bianchi type-I universe by assuming that the cosmological term is proportional to the Hubble parameter. The variation law for vacuum density was recently proposed by Schützhold on the basis of quantum field estimation in a curved expanding background. The cosmological term tends asymptotically to a genuine cosmological constant and the model tends to a de Sitter universe. We obtain that the present universe is accelerating with a large fraction of cosmological density in the form of a cosmological term</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="CN">China</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Huang Chao-Guang (Institute of High Energy Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049 (China)); Tian Yu (Graduate University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049 (China)); Wu Xiao-Ning (Institute of Mathematics, Academy of Mathematics and System Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190 (China)); Xu Zhan (Department of Physics, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084 (China)); Zhou Bin (Department of Physics, Beijing Normal University, Beijing 100875 (China)), E-mail: huangcg@ihep.ac.cn

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: New Geometry with All Killing Vectors Spanning the Poincaré Algebra

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Chinese Physics Letters; v. 29(4); ISSN 0256-307X; CODEN CPLEEU; Apr 2012; [4 p.]; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0256-307X/29/4/040303; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ALGEBRA; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LOBACHEVSKY GEOMETRY; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; SPACE-TIME; VECTORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GEOMETRY; MATHEMATICS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The new four-dimensional geometry whose Killing vectors span the Poincaré algebra is presented and its structure is analyzed. The new geometry can be regarded as the Poincaré-invariant solution of the degenerate extension of the vacuum Einstein field equations with a negative cosmological constant and provides a static cosmological spacetime with a Lobachevsky space. The motion of free particles in the spacetime is discussed. (general)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2012

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: LRS Bianchi Type-II Cosmological Model with a Decaying Lambda Term

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Chinese Physics Letters; v. 29(1); ISSN 0256-307X; CODEN CPLEEU; Jan 2012; [3 p.]; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0256-307X/29/1/010403; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; IDEAL FLOW; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUID FLOW; INCOMPRESSIBLE FLOW; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; STEADY FLOW

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We consider a locally rotationally symmetric (LRS) Bianchi type-II spacetime with a perfect fluid and a variable cosmological constant Λ. To solve the Einstein field equations we consider the cosmological term Λ to be proportional to R−m with R being the scale factor and m a constant [Phys. Rev. D 58 (1998) 043506]. In this model we obtain Λ ∼ H2, λ ∼ R-double dot/R and Lambda ∼ t−2, in agreement with the main dynamical laws for the decay of Λ. The physical significance of the cosmological model is also discussed. (general)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2012

meta.content: ACTION INTEGRAL; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC INTERACTIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; METRICS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SPACE-TIME; STRONG INTERACTIONS; SYMMETRY; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS; WEAK INTERACTIONS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTEGRALS; INTERACTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RELATIVITY THEORY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In the frame of quantum field theory, instead of using the action principle, we deduce the Einstein equation from purely the general covariant principle and the homogeneity of spacetime. The Einstein equation is shown to be the gauge equation to guarantee the local symmetry of spacetime translation. Gravity is an apparent force due to the curvature of spacetime resulted from the conservation of energy-momentum. In the action of quantum field theory, only electroweak-strong interactions should be considered with the curved spacetime metric determined by the Einstein equation. (general)

meta.content: January 2011

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The Schroedinger-Newton equation as a model for self-gravitating quantum systems

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Verhandlungen der Deutschen Physikalischen Gesellschaft; (Jena 2013 issue); ISSN 0420-0195; CODEN VDPEAZ; 2013; [1 p.]; DPG Spring meeting 2013 with the divisions physics education, extraterrestrial physics, history of physics, relativity and gravitation (together with the Astronomical Society), short-time physics, plasma physics, theoretical and mathematical foundations of physics, environmental physics and the philosophy of physics working group; DPG-Fruehjahrstagung 2013 der Fachverbaende Didaktik der Physik, Extraterrestrische Physik, Geschichte der Physik, Gravitation und Relativitaetstheorie (zusammen mit der Astronomischen Gesellschaft), Kurzzeitphysik, Plasmaphysik, Theoretische und Mathematische Grundlagen der Physik, Umweltphysik, sowie der Arbeitsgruppe Philosophie der Physik; Jena (Germany); 25 Feb - 1 Mar 2013; ; Available from http://www.dpg-verhandlungen.de; Session: GR 19.2 Fr 12:45; Also available as printed version: Verhandlungen der Deutschen Physikalischen Gesellschaft v. 48(1)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (S71); PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: DIRAC EQUATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; KLEIN-GORDON EQUATION; POWER SERIES; QUANTUM MECHANICS; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; SCHROEDINGER EQUATION; TIME DEPENDENCE; WKB APPROXIMATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: APPROXIMATIONS; BASIC INTERACTIONS; CALCULATION METHODS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTERACTIONS; MECHANICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; RELATIVITY THEORY; SERIES EXPANSION; WAVE EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The time-dependent Schroedinger-Newton equation can be considered as a model for the gravitational self-interaction of a quantum system. We motivate this model as the non-relativistic limit of a gravitationally interacting relativistic field. Namely, we show that the Schroedinger-Newton equation can be derived in a WKB-like expansion in 1/c from the Einstein-Klein-Gordon and Einstein-Dirac system.

key="21500" assignment="upposted">wave equations</descriptor> </descriptors> <qualifiers> <qualifier key="conference">Conference</qualifier> </qualifiers> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The time-dependent Schroedinger-Newton equation can be considered as a model for the gravitational self-interaction of a quantum system. We motivate this model as the non-relativistic limit of a gravitationally interacting relativistic field. Namely, we show that the Schroedinger-Newton equation can be derived in a WKB-like expansion in 1/c from the Einstein-Klein-Gordon and Einstein-Dirac system.</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="DE">Germany</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>
