meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Neutrino oscillations in the field of a rotating deformed mass

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physics Letters. A; v. 376(15); ISSN 0375-9601; CODEN PYLAAG; 12 Mar 2012; p. 1239-1243; S0375-9601(12)00204-6; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.physleta.2012.02.043; Copyright (c) 2012 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam, The Netherlands, All rights reserved.; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: APPROXIMATIONS; ASTROPHYSICS; DEFORMATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MASS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; METRICS; NEUTRINO OSCILLATION; NEUTRINOS; PHASE SHIFT

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CALCULATION METHODS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; LEPTONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; PHYSICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The neutrino oscillations in the field of a rotating deformed mass is investigated. The phase shift is evaluated in the case of weak field limit, slow rotation and small deformation. To this aim the Hartle–Thorne metric is used, which is an approximate solution of the vacuum Einstein equations accurate to second order in the rotation parameter a/M and to first order in the mass quadrupole moment q. Implications on atmospheric, solar and astrophysical neutrinos are discussed. -- Highlights: ► We consider neutrino oscillations in the field of a rotating deformed mass. ► We evaluate the phase shift in the case of weak field limit, slow rotation and small deformation. ► Observational implications are discussed.

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2012

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Black holes in realistic branes: Black string-like objects?

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physics Letters. Section B; v. 721(4-5); ISSN 0370-2693; CODEN PYLBAJ; 25 Apr 2013; p. 306-311; S0370-2693(13)00222-0; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.physletb.2013.03.010; Copyright (c) 2013 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam, The Netherlands, All rights reserved.; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; BRANES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; METRICS; M-THEORY; STANDARDS; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A realistic model describing a black string-like object in an expanding Universe is analyzed in the context of the McVittie's solution of the Einstein field equations. The bulk metric near the brane is provided analogously to previous solutions for black strings. In particular, we show that at least when the Hubble parameter on the brane is positive, a black string-like object seems to play a fundamental role in the braneworld scenario, generalizing the standard black strings in the context of a dynamical brane

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2013

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On the many-field f(R) brane

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physics Letters. Section B; v. 726(1-3); ISSN 0370-2693; CODEN PYLBAJ; 7 Oct 2013; p. 523-526; S0370-2693(13)00707-7; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.physletb.2013.08.068; Copyright (c) 2013 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam, The Netherlands, All rights reserved.; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BRANES; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; M-THEORY; SCALAR FIELDS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We consider the Randall–Sundrum braneworld theory with a single extra dimension of infinite extent to investigate generalized f(R) braneworld models in the presence of several real scalar fields. In particular, we solve the modified Einstein equations for the case of flat brane, with zero cosmological constant, and for the case of bent brane, with a nonvanishing cosmological constant. In both cases we found explicit solutions for the scalar fields with analytical expressions for the respective warp factors

meta.content: January 2013

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Manna, Goutam (Prabhat Kumar College, Department of Physics, Purba Medinipur, West Bengal (India)); Gangopadhyay, Debashis (Ramakrishna Mission Vivekananda University, Department of Physics, Howrah, West Bengal (India))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The Hawking temperature in the context of dark energy for Reissner-Nordstrom and Kerr background

meta.name: Source
meta.content: European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(3); ISSN 1434-6044; Mar 2014; p. 1-7; ; Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2811-9

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; BLACK HOLES; BORN-INFELD THEORY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; KERR METRIC; LAGRANGE EQUATIONS; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; SCALAR FIELDS; THERMAL RADIATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MATTER; METRICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RADIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: For emergent gravity metrics, the presence of dark energy modifies the Hawking temperature. We show that for the spherically symmetric Reissner-Nordstrom background metric, the emergent metric can be mapped into a Robinson-Trautman black hole. Allowed values of the dark energy density follow from rather general conditions. For some allowed values of the dark energy density this black hole can have zero Hawking temperature, i.e. the black hole does not radiate. For a Kerr background along θ = 0, the emergent black hole metric satisfies Einsteins equations for large r and always radiates. Our analysis is done in the context of emergent gravity metrics having k-essence scalar fields φ with a Born-Infeld type lagrangian. In both cases the scalar field φ(r,t) =φ1(r)+φ2(t) also satisfies the emergent gravity equations of motion for r → ∞ and θ = 0. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2014

assignment="upposted">metrics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="21631" assignment="upposted">partial differential equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08123" assignment="upposted">quantum field theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08188" assignment="upposted">radiations</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">For emergent gravity metrics, the presence of dark energy modifies the Hawking temperature. We show that for the spherically symmetric Reissner-Nordstrom background metric, the emergent metric can be mapped into a Robinson-Trautman black hole. Allowed values of the dark energy density follow from rather general conditions. For some allowed values of the dark energy density this black hole can have zero Hawking temperature, i.e. the black hole does not radiate. For a Kerr background along θ = 0, the emergent black hole metric satisfies Einsteins equations for large r and always radiates. Our analysis is done in the context of emergent gravity metrics having k-essence scalar fields φ with a Born-Infeld type lagrangian. In both cases the scalar field φ(r,t) =φ<sub>1</sub>(r)+φ<sub>2</sub>(t) also satisfies the emergent gravity equations of motion for r → ∞ and θ = 0. (orig.)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="DE">Germany</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We revisit the regular black hole found by Hayward in 4-dimensional static, spherically symmetric spacetime. To find a possible source for such a spacetime we resort to the nonlinear electrodynamics in general relativity. It is found that a magnetic field within this context gives rise to the regular Hayward black hole. By employing such a regular black hole we construct a thin-shell wormhole for the case of various equations of state on the shell. We abbreviate a general equation of state by p = ψ(σ) where p is the surface pressure which is a function of the mass density (σ). In particular, linear, logarithmic, Chaplygin, etc. forms of equations of state are considered. In each case we study the stability of the thin shell against linear perturbations.We plot the stability regions by tuning the parameters of the theory. It is observed that the role of the Hayward parameter is to make the TSW more stable. Perturbations of the throat with small velocity condition are also studied. The matter of our TSWs, however, remains exotic. (orig.)

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Full text: At this work, we will obtain a noncommutative(NC) versions for the homogeneous and isotropic Robertson- Walker universe. This cosmological model will be described by the Einstein-Hilbert(EH) action with an addition of a self-interacting scalar field action, where, ab initio, the potential is arbitrary. In order to accomplish this goal, the noncommutative Faddeev-Jackiw symplectic formalism will be applied and, as a consequence, an independent family of NC versions for the EH with self-interacting scalar field actions will be obtained. We start to investigate this NC cosmological model at the classical level, where the Hamilton-Jacobi equations of motion for each NC version of the cosmological model will be computed, which will reveal that each one leads to a distinct dynamic with an arbitrary self-interacting scalar field potential and that each NC version can not be mapped to another. After that, we start the implementation of the canonical quantization process. At this level, the canonical momenta are promoted to quantum operators and the mini-superspace Wheeler- DeWitt(WDW) equation (ΗΨ(α, ϕ) = 0, where Ψ(α, ϕ) is the wave-function of the universe) can be used as well. However, it is important to get a consistent description of the cosmological dynamics at the any time. In order to accomplish this proposal, we will determine a semi-classical analog of the deformed WDW equation. Such a classical approximation to the obtained NC WDW may be based on the Hamilton-Jacobi formulation and the WKB approach. After that, we will study the NC cosmological model for different self-interacting scalar field potential, where the critical point will be analysed. Besides of this, for a peculiar NC cosmological model, we will obtain a minimal coupling between time-dependent scalar field ((α(t)) and the scalar field (ϕ(t)), where the NC parameter plays a role of electrical charge at the electrodynamics. (author)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: From static to rotating to conformal static solutions: rotating imperfect fluid wormholes with(out) electric or magnetic field

meta.name: Source
meta.content: European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(5); ISSN 1434-6044; May 2014; p. 1-11; ; Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2865-8

meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BLACK HOLES; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; CONFORMAL MAPPING; DUSTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN-MAXWELL EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC FIELDS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; FLUIDS; MAGNETIC FIELDS; METRICS; ROTATION; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MAPPING; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MOTION; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We derive a shortcut stationary metric formula for generating imperfect fluid rotating solutions, in Boyer-Lindquist coordinates, from spherically symmetric static ones. We explore the properties of the curvature scalar and stress-energy tensor for all types of rotating regular solutions we can generate without restricting ourselves to specific examples of regular solutions (regular black holes or wormholes). We show through examples how it is generally possible to generate an imperfect fluid regular rotating solution via radial coordinate transformations. We derive rotating wormholes that are modeled as imperfect fluids and discuss their physical properties. These are independent on the way the stress-energy tensor is interpreted. A solution modeling an imperfect fluid rotating loop black hole is briefly discussed. We then specialize to the recently discussed stable exotic dust Ellis wormhole as emerged in a source-free radial electric or magnetic field, and we generate its, conjecturally stable, rotating counterpart. This turns out to be an exotic imperfect fluid wormhole, and we determine the stress-energy tensor of both the imperfect fluid and the electric or magnetic field. (orig.)

meta.content: January 2014

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The calculation of the full (renormalized) holographic action is undertaken in general Einstein-scalar theories. The appropriate formalism is developed and the renormalized effective action is calculated up to two derivatives in the metric and scalar operators. The holographic RG equations involve a generalized Ricci flow for the space-time metric as well as the standard β-function flow for scalar operators. Several examples are analyzed and the effective action is calculated. A set of conserved quantities of the holographic flow is found, whose interpretation is not yet understood. (Copyright copyright 2014 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH and Co. KGaA, Weinheim)

key="09317" assignment="upposted">space</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The calculation of the full (renormalized) holographic action is undertaken in general Einstein-scalar theories. The appropriate formalism is developed and the renormalized effective action is calculated up to two derivatives in the metric and scalar operators. The holographic RG equations involve a generalized Ricci flow for the space-time metric as well as the standard β-function flow for scalar operators. Several examples are analyzed and the effective action is calculated. A set of conserved quantities of the holographic flow is found, whose interpretation is not yet understood. (Copyright copyright 2014 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH and Co. KGaA, Weinheim)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="DE">Germany</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: García-Diaz, Alberto A. (Departamento de Física, Centro de Investigación y de Estudios Avanzados del IPN, Apdo. Postal 14-740, 07000 México DF, México. and Departamento de Física, Universidad Autónoma Metropolitana-Iztapalapa, Apdo. (Mexico))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Dilaton field minimally coupled to 2+1 gravity; uniqueness of the static Chan-Mann black hole and new dilaton stationary metrics

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: AIP Conference Proceedings; v. 1577(1); ISSN 0094-243X; CODEN APCPCS; 14 Jan 2014; p. 220-235; 5. Leopoldo Garcia-Colin Mexican meeting on mathematical and experimental physics; Mexico City (Mexico); 9-13 Sep 2013; (c) 2014 AIP Publishing LLC; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: MATHEMATICAL METHODS AND COMPUTING (S97); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; GRAVITATION; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; SERIES EXPANSION; SINGULARITY; TENSORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Using the Schwarzschild coordinate frame for a static cyclic symmetric metric in 2+1 gravity coupled minimally to a dilaton logarithmically depending on the radial coordinate in the presence of an exponential potential, by solving first order linear Einstein equations, the general solution is derived and it is identified with the Chan–Mann dilaton solution. In these coordinates, a new stationary dilaton solution is obtained; it does not allow for a de Sitter–Anti-de Sitter limit at spatial infinity, where its structural functions increase indefinitely. On the other hand, it is horizonless and allows for a naked singularity at the origin of coordinates; moreover, one can identify at a large radial coordinate a (quasi-local) mass parameter and in the whole space a constant angular momentum. Via a general SL(2,R)–transformation, applied on the static cyclic symmetric metric, a family of stationary dilaton solutions has been generated. A particular SL(2,R)–transformation is identified, which gives rise to the rotating Chan–Mann dilaton solution. All the exhibited solutions have been characterized by their quasi-local energy, mass, and momentum through their series expansions at spatial infinity. The algebraic structure of the Ricci–energy-momentum, and Cotton tensors is given explicitly

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2014

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Romano, Antonio Enea (Yukawa Institute for Theoretical Physics and Physics Department, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606-8502 (Japan)), E-mail: aer@yukawa.kyoto-u.ac.jp

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Can the cosmological constant be mimicked by smooth large-scale inhomogeneities for more than one observable?

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2010(05); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 May 2010; p. 020; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2010/05/020; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ACCELERATION; ASTROPHYSICS; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GEOMETRY; LUMINOSITY; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; RED SHIFT; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICS; MATTER; OPTICAL PROPERTIES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; PHYSICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: As an alternative to dark energy it has been suggested that we may be at the center of an inhomogeneous isotropic universe described by a Lemaitre-Tolman-Bondi (LTB) solution of Einstein's field equations. In order to test such an hypothesis we calculate the low redshift expansion of the luminosity distance DL(z) and the redshift spherical shell mass density mn(z) for a central observer in a LTB space without cosmological constant and show how they cannot fit the observations implied by a ΛCDM model if the conditions to avoid a weak central singularity are imposed, i.e. if the matter distribution is smooth everywhere. Our conclusions are valid for any value of the cosmological constant, not only for ΩΛ > 1/3 as implied by previous proofs that qapp0 has to be positive in a smooth LTB space, based on considering only the luminosity distance. The observational signatures of smooth LTB matter dominated models are fundamentally different from the ones of ΛCDM models not only because it is not possible to reproduce a negative apparent central deceleration qapp0, but because of deeper differences in their space-time geometry which make impossible solve the inversion problem when more than one observable is considered, and emerge at any redshift, not only for z = 0

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2010

meta.content: Romano, Antonio Enea (Yukawa Institute for Theoretical Physics, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606-8502 (Japan)), E-mail: aer@yukawa.kyoto-u.ac.jp

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Testing homogeneity with galaxy number counts: light-cone metric and general low-redshift expansion for a central observer in a matter dominated isotropic universe without cosmological constant

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.content: Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2010(01); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Jan 2010; p. 004; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2010/01/004; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GALAXIES; GAUGE INVARIANCE; LIGHT CONE; LUMINOSITY; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; METRICS; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; RED SHIFT; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATTER; OPTICAL PROPERTIES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: As an alternative to dark energy it has been suggested that we may be at the center of an inhomogeneous isotropic universe described by a Lemaitre-Tolman-Bondi (LTB) solution of Einstein's field equations. In order to test this hypothesis we calculate the general analytical formula to fifth order for the redshift spherical shell mass. Using the same analytical method we write the metric in the light-cone by introducing a gauge invariant quantity G(z) which together with the luminosity distance DL(z) completely determine the light-cone geometry of a LTB model

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2010

meta.content: APPROXIMATIONS; CALCULATION METHODS; CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INFORMATION; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Many discussion about the black hole conundrums, such like singularity and information loss, suggested that there must be some essential irreconcilable conflict between quantum theory and classical gravity theory, which cannot be solved with any semiclassical quantized model of gravity, the only feasible way must be some complete unified quantum theory of gravity. In Vachaspati, the arguments indicate the possibility of an alternate outcome of gravitational collapse which avoids the information loss problem. In this paper, also with semiclassical analysis, it shows that so long as the mechanism of black hole evaporation satisfies a quite loose condition that the evaporation lifespan is finite for external observers, regardless of the detailed mechanism and process of evaporation, the conundrums above can be naturally avoided. This condition can be satisfied with Hawking-Unruh mechanism. Thus, the conflict between quantum theory and classical gravity theory may be not as serious as it seemed to be, the effectiveness of semiclassical methods might be underestimated. An exact universal solution with spherical symmetry of Einstein field equation has been derived in this paper. All possible solutions with spherical symmetry of Einstein field equation are its special cases. In addition, some problems of the Penrose diagram of an evaporating black hole first introduced by Hawking in 1975 are clarified

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2011

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; EVALUATION; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; OPTICAL PROPERTIES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SYMMETRY; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The Szekeres inhomogeneous models can be used to model the true lumpy universe that we observe. This family of exact solutions to Einstein's equations was originally derived with a general metric that has no symmetries. In this work, we develop and use a framework to integrate the angular diameter and luminosity distances in the general Szekeres models. We use the affine null geodesic equations in order to derive a set of first-order ordinary differential equations that can be integrated numerically to calculate the partial derivatives of the null vector components. These equations allow the integration in all generality of the distances in the Szekeres models and some examples are given. The redshift is determined from simultaneous integration of the null geodesic equations. This work does not assume spherical or axial symmetry, and the results will be useful for comparisons of the general Szekeres inhomogeneous models to current and future cosmological data

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2011

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Ambiguous tests of general relativity on cosmological scales

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2012(06); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Jun 2012; p. 032; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2012/06/032; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; PERTURBATION THEORY; SOLAR SYSTEM; SPACE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PHYSICS; RELATIVITY THEORY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: There are a number of approaches to testing General Relativity (GR) on linear scales using parameterized frameworks for modifying cosmological perturbation theory. It is sometimes assumed that the details of any given parameterization are unimportant if one uses it as a diagnostic for deviations from GR. In this brief report we argue that this is not necessarily so. First we show that adopting alternative combinations of modifications to the field equations significantly changes the constraints that one obtains. In addition, we show that using a parameterization with insufficient freedom significantly tightens the apparent theoretical constraints. Fundamentally we argue that it is almost never appropriate to consider modifications to the perturbed Einstein equations as being constraints on the effective gravitational constant, for example, in the same sense that solar system constraints are. The only consistent modifications are either those that grant near-total freedom, as in decomposition methods, or ones which map directly to a particular part of theory space

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2012

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: APPROXIMATIONS; ASTROPHYSICS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; CORRECTIONS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; HYDRODYNAMICS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; PERTURBATION THEORY; RELATIVISTIC RANGE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CALCULATION METHODS; ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; EVALUATION; FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; PHYSICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We present the general relativistic pressure correction terms in Newtonian hydrodynamic equations to the nonlinear order: these are equations (1.1)–(1.3). The derivation is made in the zero-shear gauge based on the fully nonlinear formulation of cosmological perturbation in Einstein's gravity. The correction terms differ from many of the previously suggested forms in the literature based on hand-waving manners. We confirm our results by comparing with (i) the nonlinear perturbation theory, (ii) the first order post-Newtonian approximation, and (iii) the special relativistic limit, and by checking (iv) the consistency with full Einstein's equation

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2013

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Spherically symmetric cosmological spacetimes with dust and radiation — numerical implementation

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2013(10); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Oct 2013; p. 010; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2013/10/010; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: APPROXIMATIONS; COSMOLOGY; DECOUPLING; DEGREES OF FREEDOM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; LUMINOSITY; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; NUCLEOSYNTHESIS; RED SHIFT; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; SPACE-TIME; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; SYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: CALCULATION METHODS; CONFIGURATION; ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATTER; OPTICAL PROPERTIES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SYNTHESIS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We present new numerical cosmological solutions of the Einstein Field Equations. The spacetime is spherically symmetric with a source of dust and radiation approximated as a perfect fluid. The dust and radiation are necessarily non-comoving due to the inhomogeneity of the spacetime. Such a model can be used to investigate non-linear general relativistic effects present during decoupling or big-bang nucleosynthesis, as well as for investigating void models of dark energy with isocurvature degrees of freedom. We describe the full evolution of the spacetime as well as the redshift and luminosity distance for a central observer. After demonstrating accuracy of the code, we consider a few example models, and demonstrate the sensitivity of the late time model to the degree of inhomogeneity of the initial radiation contrast

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2013

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Distance-redshift relations in an anisotropic cosmological model

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2013(03); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Mar 2013; p. 033; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2013/03/033; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANISOTROPY; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DISTANCE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY SPECTRA; EXACT SOLUTIONS; METRICS; RED SHIFT; SUPERNOVAE; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BINARY STARS; EQUATIONS; ERUPTIVE VARIABLE STARS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; SPECTRA; STARS; VARIABLE STARS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In this paper we study an anisotropic model generated from a particular Bianchi type-III metric, which is a generalization of Gödel's metric and an exact solution of Einstein's field equations. We analyse type Ia supernova data, namely the SDSS sample calibrated with the MLCS2k2 fitter, and we verify in which ranges of distances and redshifts the anisotropy could be observed. We also consider, in a joint analysis, the position of the first peak in the CMB anisotropy spectrum, as well as current observational constraints on the Hubble constant. We conclude that a small anisotropy is permitted by the data, and that more accurate measurements of supernova distances above z = 2 might indicate the existence of such anisotropy in the universe

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2013

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We solve the Einstein equation in five-dimensional space-time for Randall-Sundrum Brane world model with time dependent radion field to study the variation of brane scale factor with time. We have shown that as the radion field decreases with time compactifying the extra dimension, the scale factor increases exponentially with time leading to an inflationary scenario. We have also proposed a time dependent generalization of the Goldberger-Wise moduli stabilization mechanism to explain the time evolution of the radion field to reach a stable value, after which the scale factor on the brane exits from inflationary expansion. (orig.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2014

meta.name: DEC

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We consider discretizations of the Einstein action of general relativity such that the resulting discrete equations of motion form a consistent constrained system. Upon 'spin foam' quantization of the system, consistency allows a natural way of recovering the correct semi-classical theory. A consistent set of approximations to the Einstein equations could also have implications for numerical relativity and for the construction of approximate classical observables for the theory. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2002

Upon 'spin foam' quantization of the system, consistency allows a natural way of recovering the correct semi-classical theory. A consistent set of approximations to the Einstein equations could also have implications for numerical relativity and for the construction of approximate classical observables for the theory. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="BG">Bulgaria</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.content: Obozov, V.I. (Orenburgskij Politekhnicheskij Inst. (USSR))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On nonstatic gravitational fields of ideal liquid without shift rotation

meta.name: Title
meta.content: O nestaticheskikh gravitatsionnykh polyakh ideal'noj zhidkosti bez sdviga i vrashchniya

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika; (no.8) p. 71-76; ISSN 0021-3411; 1979; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics Journal (USA).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GALERKIN-PETROV METHOD; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LIQUIDS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FLUIDS; ITERATIVE METHODS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Using the integrability conditions for the equations of the velocity field of particles with zero shift and zero rotation and for the classification of space in types, it has been elucidated which type of space satisfies the above mentioned equations. First it is shown that the tensors of conformal curvature of the spaces under investigation should satisfy a certain relation. It is found that among nonconformal-planar nonstatic gravitation fields of an ideal liquid without shift and rotation there are no fields with spaces of the 1(D-type), 2(N-type), and 3 types according to the Petrov classification. It has been concluded that a set of conformal-planar nonstatic gravitation fields of an ideal liquid without shift and rotation of particles in the Einstein gravitational theory is an empty set

meta.content: January 1979

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: d'Inverno, R.A.; Smallwood, J. (Faculty of Mathematics, Southampton University, SO9 5NH, England)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Covariant 2+2 formulation of the initial-value problem in general relativity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 22(6) p. 1233-1247; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Sep 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; SPACE-TIME; VACUUM STATES; VECTOR FIELDS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A covariant 2+2 formalism is developed in which space-time is decomposed into a family of spacelike two-surfaces and their orthogonal timelike two-surface elements. The resulting 2+2 breakup of the Einstein vacuum field equations is then used to investigate covariant formulations of spacelike, characteristic, and mixed initial-value problems. In each case the so-called conformal two-structure (essentially the conformal metric of a family of spacelike two-surfaces) is identified as the freely specifiable initial data. The formalism makes clear the geometrical significance of both the initial data and the various choices of gauge variables. A Lagrangian formulation is included which supports the role of the conformal two-structure as dynamical variables of the pure gravitational field

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Kates, R.E. (Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02138)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Gravitational radiation damping of a binary system containing compact objects calculated using matched asymptotic expansions

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 22(8) p. 1871-1878; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Oct 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; BINARY STARS; DAMPING; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; ORBITS; PULSARS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: COSMIC RADIO SOURCES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; RADIATIONS; STARS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: This paper calculates the secular changes in orbital period, semimajor axis, and eccentricity for a gravitationally bound, slow-motion system of two compact bodies, directly from the Einstein field equation, using matched asymptotic expansions. Burke previously derived the radiation damping of a weak-field, slow-motion system, also using matched asymptotic expansions. However, no previous derivations extend to systems, such as the binary pulsar PSR 1913+16, containing objects with strong internal gravity. This calculation uses distinct wave-, near-, and body-zone expansions to seek a uniformly valid, one-parameter family of approximate space-times representing a bound system of compact objects undergoing gravitational radiation reaction. As in Burke's work, matching outward gives the lowest-order near-zone and radiation fields, and then matching back inward yields near-zone resistive potentials of 5/2-post-Newtonian order, which contain the lowest-order time-odd effects of radiation. Matching inward again using my earlier technique for the problem of motion in external fields then gives the resulting deflections of the bodies from the world lines that they would otherwise follow. The secular changes in orbital parameters derived for the system of compact objects treated here agree with the standard formulas obeyed by weak-field systems

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Hojman, R.; Mukku, C.; Sayed, W.A. (Advanced School of Physics, Trieste, Italy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Parity violation in metric-torsion theories of gravitation

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 22(8) p. 1915-1921; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Oct 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COUPLING CONSTANTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; METRICS; P INVARIANCE; SPACE-TIME; TENSOR FORCES; TORSION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The general structure of metric-torsion theories of gravitation is shown to allow a parity-violating contribution to the complete action which is linear in the curvature tensor and vanishes identically in the absence of torsion. The resulting action involves apart from the Newtonian constant a coupling which governs the strength of the predicted parity-nonconserving ''interactions'' mediated by torsion. We consider this theory in the presence of the Proca field and show that it leads to a parity-violating term in the field equations in contrast to the Einstein-Cartan-Sciama-Kibble theory, which we use as a particularly simple example of a metric-torsion theory of gravitation

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Anderson, J.L.; Kegeles, L.S. (Stevens Inst. of Tech., Hoboken, NJ (USA). Dept. of Physics)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Causes and cures for the infinities in slow-motion expansions in general relativity

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 12(8) p 633-647; ISSN 0001-7701; Aug 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BINARY STARS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; ISOTROPY; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; OSCILLATORS; PERTURBATION THEORY; SCALAR FIELDS; SERIES EXPANSION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; STARS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The causes of the divergent integrals arising in slow-motion expansions of the general relativistic field equations are studied and a remedy for them is suggested. This is done within the context of a model problem involving a coupled nonlinear scalar field and isotropic oscillator. The model is shown to give rise to divergent integrals directly attributable to the nonlinearity when the field is assumed to be analytic in a slowness parameter. Application of a nonregular perturbation approach which includes the method of matched asymptotic expansions is shown to eliminate the infinite contributions. (author)

meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Production of gravitation waves by electromagnetic radiation

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Erzeugung von gravitationswellen durch elektromagnetische strahlung

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United Kingdom

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 13(10) p. L371-L374; ISSN 0305-4470; Oct 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; AXIAL SYMMETRY; COMPLEX MANIFOLDS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; FREQUENCY DEPENDENCE; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; RADIATIONS; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: An exact solution of Einstein's equations is presented that corresponds to an axisymmetric bundle of electromagnetic waves with finite cross section. Outside this bundle, there is gravitational radiation parallel to the electromagnetic radiation. If no static electromagnetic fields are present, the frequency of the gravitational waves is twice the frequency of the electromagnetic waves. Einstein's energy complex vanishes identically. The covariant energy complex, however, yields also a radial momentum. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BASIC INTERACTIONS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTERACTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LEPTONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS; PARTICLE PRODUCTION; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We examine the gravitational coupling of neutrinos to matter vorticity; in the context of the Einstein theory of gravitation and for technical simplicity, we have considered the Goedel model as the cosmological background, whose matter content has a non-null vorticity. The presence of a vorticity field of matter generates, via gravitation, microscopic asymmetries in neutrino physics. At the microscopic level, currents are asymmetric along the direction determined by the vorticity field: Neutrino (antineutrino) currents are larger along the direction antiparallel (parallel) to the vorticity field. In the case of production of pairs under CP violation, a net number asymmetry is generated between neutrinos and antineutrinos

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Fennelly, A.J. (Physics and Astronomy Department, Western Kentucky University, Bowling Green, Kentucky 42101)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Observer frame rotation rates and magnetic fields in spatially homogeneous universes

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COORDINATES; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUID FLOW; MAGNETIC FIELDS; ROTATION; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We discuss how the rotation of an observer's Cartesian reference frame is related to the precession of the shear tensor's principal axes and to the rotation vector of the fluid. An approximate solution of Einstein's equations illuminates this relationship further. In the case with a magnetic field and fluid flow a vorticity is allowed in Bianchi I cosmologies

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Hiscock, W.H. (Physics Department, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut 06520)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Magnetic charge, black holes, and cosmic censorship

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Annals of Physics (New York); v. 131(2) p. 245-268; ISSN 0003-4916; Feb 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; DUALITY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; STAR ACCRETION; TEST PARTICLES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; STAR EVOLUTION

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The possibility of converting a Reissner-Nordstroem black hole into a naked singularity by means of test particle accretion is considered. The dually charged Reissner-Nordstroem metric describes a black hole only when M2>Q2+P2. The test particle equations of motion are shown to allow test particles with arbitrarily large magnetic charge/mass ratios to fall radially into electrically charged black holes. To determine the nature of the final state (black hole or naked singularity) an exact solution of Einstein's equations representing a spherical shell of magnetically charged dust falling into an electrically charged black hole is studied. Naked singularities are never formed so long as the weak energy condition is obeyed by the infalling matter. The differences between the spherical shell model and an infalling point test particle are examined and discussed

record.content: <html><head><META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head><body><inisrecord> <action trn="US8112936" type="add" /> <record role="document" source-system="fibre" trn="US8112936" type="journal" rn="12630230"> <publication> <titles> <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">Magnetic charge, black holes, and cosmic censorship</title> </titles> <date value="1981-02-" sici-chronology="198102">Feb 1981</date> <country key="US">United States</country> <creators and-others="no"> <creator type="personal">Hiscock, W.H.</creator> <creator type="affiliation">Physics Department, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut 06520</creator> </creators> <availability inis="no"> <contact>Bibliographic information available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:12630230</contact> </availability> <is-part-of> <journal> <titles> <title type="primary">Annals of Physics (New York)</title> <title type="abbreviated">Ann. Phys. (N.Y.)</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0003-4916</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 131(2) p. 245-268.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1100" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="01114" assignment="indexer">black holes</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02795" assignment="indexer">duality</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="04115" assignment="indexer">gravitational collapse</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09152" assignment="indexer">singularity</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="12276" assignment="indexer">star accretion</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09957" assignment="indexer">test particles</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09453" assignment="upposted">star evolution</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The possibility of converting a Reissner-Nordstroem black hole into a naked singularity by means of test particle accretion is considered. The dually charged Reissner-Nordstroem metric describes a black hole only when M<sup>2</sup>>Q<sup>2</sup>+P<sup>2</sup>. The test particle equations of motion are shown to allow test particles with arbitrarily large magnetic charge/mass ratios to fall radially into electrically charged black holes. To determine the nature of the final state (black hole or naked singularity) an exact solution of Einstein's equations representing a spherical shell of magnetically charged dust falling into an electrically charged black hole is studied. Naked singularities are never formed so long as the weak energy condition is obeyed by the infalling matter. The differences between the spherical shell model and an infalling point test particle are examined and discussed</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: DEC

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A problem was set to write down gravity equations and to investigate possibility to solve them for the case when four-interval square is giVen in spherical ''radiation'' coordinates u, r, THETA, phi. Central-symmetrical gravitational fields are analyzed depending on conditions imposed on the right part of the Einstein equations. Analysis has been conducted by means of the Newman-Penrose formalism and proof of the Birkhof theorem of obligatory statical character of an external gravitational field of a spherical-symmetrical source

meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Krechet, V.G.; Shikin, G.N. (Moskovskij Vechernij Metallurgicheskij Inst. (USSR))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Scalar and electromagnetic fields in the Kazner metric. Interaction as an isotropization mechanism

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Skalyarnoe i ehlektromagnitnoe polya v metrike Kaznera: vzaimodejstvie kak mekhanizm izotropizatsii

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika; v. 24(7) p. 67-70; ISSN 0021-3411; Jul 1981; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics Journal (USA).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANISOTROPY; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC FIELDS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; EXPANSION; ISOTROPY; METRICS; SCALAR FIELDS; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A new isotropization mechanism for expansion of the anisotropic cosmological model proposed as a result of direct interaction of a scalar and an electromagnetic fields. It is shown that isotropization of the model occurs as a result of disappearance of the electric field, giving rise to anisotropy in the initial phase of evolution, and increase of the scalar field ensuring the isotropic character of expansion. Disappearance of the electric field agrees with the present observed data on the absense of the global electric field in the Universe. In the classical approach the solutions of the system of the Einstein equations and interacting scalar and electromagnetic fields are studied. The range of the interaction parameter, at which expansion of the Universe becomes isotropic, is determined. The conclusion is made that isotropization of the anisotropic Kazner model with the scalar and electromagnetic fields occurs only in the case when direct interaction exists between the fields

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: Pagels, H.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Rockefeller Univ., New York (USA)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Cosmological term and supersymmetry invited talk at Orbis Scientia, 1981

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: 1981; 10 p; Orbis scientiae conference; Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA; 19 - 22 Jan 1981; DOE/EV/40033--1; CONF-810134--3; ; Available from NTIS., PC A02/MF A01 as DE82007560

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SUPERSYMMETRY; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A persistent problem in quantum field theory is the existence of vacuum energy which is defined by the expectation value of theta/sub μν/ = 1/F2/ gμ where theta/sub μν/ is the stress-energy tensor and F is a constant. Why is this a problem. For all field theories with the exception of gravity the value of F is of no importance - it corresponds to a uniform background vacuum energy density throughout space. Since all energy levels are measured relative to the vacuum energy this quantity is unobservable. However, the Einstein equations for the gravity field know about energy in the vacuum and for F-1 approx. (GeV)2, corresponding to typical value from hadron physics, they imply that the universe curls up into a little ball about 100 meters in diameter, contrary to experience. This is the vacuum energy problem and it was first emphasized by Ya. B. Zel'dovich. One way out is to simply subtract away the vacuum energy. This ad hoc procedure - while it is what usually is done - must be viewed as unnatural because it has no basis in symmetry. The empirically observed absence of vacuum energy should have an explanation in terms of symmetry - like the absence of a photon mass is explained by a local gauge symmetry of the vacuum. Here we will show that such a symmetry of the coupled matter and gravity fields is indeed present up to terms of 0(kappa2) where kappa is the gravitational coupling constant. Our work should be viewed as a first step towards a more complete understanding of this problem

meta.name: Abstract1
meta.content: step towards a more complete understanding of this problem

meta.content: January 1981

Why is this a problem. For all field theories with the exception of gravity the value of F is of no importance - it corresponds to a uniform background vacuum energy density throughout space. Since all energy levels are measured relative to the vacuum energy this quantity is unobservable. However, the Einstein equations for the gravity field know about energy in the vacuum and for F<sup>-1</sup> approx. (GeV)<sup>2</sup>, corresponding to typical value from hadron physics, they imply that the universe curls up into a little ball about 100 meters in diameter, contrary to experience. This is the vacuum energy problem and it was first emphasized by Ya. B. Zel'dovich. One way out is to simply subtract away the vacuum energy. This ad hoc procedure - while it is what usually is done - must be viewed as unnatural because it has no basis in symmetry. The empirically observed absence of vacuum energy should have an explanation in terms of symmetry - like the absence of a photon mass is explained by a local gauge symmetry of the vacuum. Here we will show that such a symmetry of the coupled matter and gravity fields is indeed present up to terms of 0(kappa<sup>2</sup>) where kappa is the gravitational coupling constant. Our work should be viewed as a first step towards a more complete understanding of this problem</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUASI PARTICLES; SPACE; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Within the framework of differential geometry, Yang's parallel-displacement gauge theory is considered with respect to ''pure'' gravitational fields. In a four-dimensional Riemannian manifold it is shown that the double self-dual solutions obey Einstein's vacuum equations with the cosmological term, whereas the double anti-self-dual configurations satisfy the Rainich conditions of Wheeler's geometrodynamics. Conformal methods reveal that the gravitational analog of the ''instanton'' or pseudoparticle solution of Yang-Mills theory was already known to Riemann. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.content: High frequency background quantization of gravity

meta.content: United States

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUCTUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; RICCI TENSOR

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; TENSORS; VARIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Considering background quantization of gravitational fields, it is generally assumed that the classical background satisfies Einstein's gravitational equations. However, there exist arguments showing that, for high frequency (quantum) fluctuations, this assumption has to be replaced by a condition describing the back reaction of fluctuations on the background. It is shown that such an approach leads to limitations for the quantum procedure which occur at distances larger than Planck's elementary length 1 = (Gh/c3)/sup 1/2/

meta.content: January 1982

Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Trieste (Italy); 5 - 11 Jul 1979

meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BAECKLUND TRANSFORMATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; VECTORS

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; TENSORS; TRANSFORMATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Baecklund transformations, by which one obtains new solutions of differential equations from old ones by means of quadratures, have been used recently in investigating a number of equations of physics. A Baecklund transformation (BT) for the Ernst equation of general relativity has recently been found. Two different calculations of that result are presented here. As an example, it is shown how to use the BT to find new solutions from the Weyl or Einstein-Rosen metrics. (Auth.)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Shikin, I.S. (Institute of Mechanics, Moscow State University)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Investigation of self-similar gravitational fields in space-time with plane symmetry

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Soviet Physics - JETP; v. 54(3) p. 427-433; Sep 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CONFORMAL GROUPS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; SHOCK WAVES; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: For matter with equation of state p = (γ-1)e, gravitational fields with plane symmetry that admit the conformal group with a dependence of the metric on z = x1/x0 (self-similar solutions in space-time with plane symmetry) are considered in the general theory of relatively. The investigation of the Einstein equations, which reduce to a system of ordinary differential equations, requires a qualitative investigation on a two-dimensional phase plane. Some exact solutions are given. The t region (z coordinate timelike) and the s region (z coordinate spacelike) are introduced. A special case of metric structure containing the flat Friedmann model is considered in detail. The construction of analytic solutions and solutions with weak and strong discontinuities (shock waves and contact discontinuities) is discussed. Solutions which can be joined to the flat Friedmann model through a weak discontinuity and through a shock wave are studied. The possibility of joining the flat Friedmann model to Minkowski space-time through a shock wave of limiting intensity is discussed

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

record.content: <html><head><META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head><body><inisrecord> <action trn="US8215366" type="add" /> <record role="document" source-system="fibre" trn="US8215366" type="journal" rn="14743708"> <publication> <titles> <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">Investigation of self-similar gravitational fields in space-time with plane symmetry</title> </titles> <date value="1981-09-" sici-chronology="198109">Sep 1981</date> <country key="US">United States</country> <creators and-others="no"> <creator type="personal">Shikin, I.S.</creator> <creator type="affiliation">Institute of Mechanics, Moscow State University</creator> </creators> <availability inis="no"> <contact>Bibliographic information available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:14743708</contact> </availability> <is-part-of> <journal> <titles> <title type="primary">Soviet Physics - JETP</title> <title type="abbreviated">Sov. Phys. - JETP (Engl. Transl.)</title> </titles> <physical-description>v. 54(3) p. 427-433.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1100" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="00389" assignment="indexer">analytical solution</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11669" assignment="indexer">conformal groups</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11998" assignment="indexer">gravitational fields</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="indexer">metrics</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09036" assignment="indexer">shock waves</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="05490" assignment="upposted">lie groups</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="09721" assignment="upposted">symmetry groups</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">For matter with equation of state p = (γ-1)e, gravitational fields with plane symmetry that admit the conformal group with a dependence of the metric on z = x<sup>1</sup>/x<sup>0</sup> (self-similar solutions in space-time with plane symmetry) are considered in the general theory of relatively. The investigation of the Einstein equations, which reduce to a system of ordinary differential equations, requires a qualitative investigation on a two-dimensional phase plane. Some exact solutions are given. The t region (z coordinate timelike) and the s region (z coordinate spacelike) are introduced. A special case of metric structure containing the flat Friedmann model is considered in detail. The construction of analytic solutions and solutions with weak and strong discontinuities (shock waves and contact discontinuities) is discussed. Solutions which can be joined to the flat Friedmann model through a weak discontinuity and through a shock wave are studied. The possibility of joining the flat Friedmann model to Minkowski space-time through a shock wave of limiting intensity is discussed</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Westpfahl, K.; Hoyler, H. (Freiburg Univ. (Germany, F.R.). Fakultaet fuer Physik)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Gravitational bremsstrahlung in post-linear fast-motion approximation

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 27(17) p. 581-585; ISSN 0024-1318; 26 Apr 1980

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BREMSSTRAHLUNG; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; QUADRUPOLES; TWO-BODY PROBLEM

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MANY-BODY PROBLEM; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MULTIPOLES; RADIATIONS; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: A solution for the post-linear Einstein equations in a two-body problem is proposed, in order to point out that the bremsstrahlung generated by gravitationally scattered point masses is obtainable as lowest order in the masses, for relativistic velocities. It is emphasized that the Einstein quadrupole formula emerges only considering post-linear approximations. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1980

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Cervero, J.; Estevez, P.G. (Departamento de Fisica Teorica, Facultad de Ciencias, Salamanca (Spain))

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Spontaneous breakdown of the vacuum in the gauge-covariant theory of gravitation

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 30(11) p. 323-326; ISSN 0024-1318; 14 Mar 1981

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; SCALE DIMENSION; SCALE INVARIANCE; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In the context of the gauge covariant theory of gravitation it is shown that, if one wishes to recover Einstein's equations to define the so-called gravitational units, there are, in the vacuum case, two possible gravitational gauges; nevertheless, they establish a different set of units, and, therefore, a degeneracy arises which has to be removed using physical assumptions. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1981

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Cosmological term and torsion of space-time

meta.name: Title
meta.content: Kosmologicheskij chlen i kruchenie prostranstva-vremeni

meta.name: Source

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMIC DUST; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; METRICS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SPACE-TIME; SPIN; TWISTOR THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; BASIC INTERACTIONS; DUSTS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The solutions of the field equations of the Einstein-Cartan theory are obtained. They describe the uniform and isotopic distribution of spinning dust. Unlike the previous papers, concerning the cosmological solutions of the theory, this paper asserts that particle spin distribution is chaotically disoriented. After averaging non-zero, quadratic terms of spin density remain. The analogy between cosmologic spin of space-time and a #betta#-term is pointed out. The solution obtained is joined with the external metric of the Robertson-Worker type

meta.content: January 1982

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Mayer, S.P.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Wisconsin Univ., Milwaukee (USA)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Angular momentum in curved spacetimes

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANGULAR MOMENTUM; CHARGED PARTICLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; SPACE-TIME

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The first part of this thesis concerns the quantization of charge. It has long been known that the electromagnetic field generated by an electric charge e and a (hypothetical) magnetic charge g contains a net angular momentum eg which is independent of the separation between the charges. If we demand that this angular momentum be quantized, then we obtain the relation eg = 1/2 nh, identical to that which Dirac obtained in 1931 by requiring that the wave function of a charged particle be well defined in the presence of a magnetic monopole. Dirac's argument can be generalized to curved spacetime, and it is interesting to ask whether the angular-momentum approach can also be generalized. To answer this question we consider a metric with axial Killing vector phi/sup a/, and calculate the angular momentum contained in the field of two charges e and g located on the axis of symmetry. We show that it still equals eg, regardless of the separation. The aim of the second part is to show that a nonvanishing angular momentum, as defined by a surface integral at infinity, can exist when in an axisymmetric vacuum spacetime whose spacelike hypersurfaces are compact inside the surface of integration. (If a global Killing vector were present then the vanishing of the energy-momentum tensor would imply that the angular momentum vanishes as well.) A 3-space S is constructed which has a topological handle that prevents us from defining a Killing vector globally, but which admits a rotational Killing pseudovector - that is, a vector field up to sign. We ensure that S can be evolved forward in time according to the vacuum Einstein equations by constructing two tensors p/sup ab/ and g/sup ab/ on S which satisfy the initial value equations. After deriving a formula for the angular momentum in terms of this initial data, we are able to show that it can be made nonzero

meta.name: Abstract1
meta.content: vector globally, but which admits a rotational Killing pseudovector - that is, a vector field up to sign. We ensure that S can be evolved forward in time according to the vacuum Einstein equations by constructing two tensors p/sup ab/ and g/sup ab/ on S which satisfy the initial value equations. After deriving a formula for the angular momentum in terms of this initial data, we are able to show that it can be made nonzero

If we demand that this angular momentum be quantized, then we obtain the relation eg = 1/2 nh, identical to that which Dirac obtained in 1931 by requiring that the wave function of a charged particle be well defined in the presence of a magnetic monopole. To answer this question we consider a metric with axial Killing vector phi/sup a/, and calculate the angular momentum contained in the field of two charges e and g located on the axis of symmetry. We show that it still equals eg, regardless of the separation. (If a global Killing vector were present then the vanishing of the energy-momentum tensor would imply that the angular momentum vanishes as well.) A 3-space S is constructed which has a topological handle that prevents us from defining a Killing vector globally, but which admits a rotational Killing pseudovector - that is, a vector field up to sign. We ensure that S can be evolved forward in time according to the vacuum Einstein equations by constructing two tensors p/sup ab/ and g/sup ab/ on S which satisfy the initial value equations. meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The evolution of the cosmological scale factors are studied in a five dimensional cosmology that has a non-vanishing divergence of the energy momentum tensor. Cosmologies driven by pure radiation, dust, and the false vacuum are studied and the results compared with standard Friedman cosmology along with cosmologies governed by Einstein's equations in five dimensions. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Shen, T.C.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Maryland Univ., College Park (USA)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Quantum effects in non-maximally symmetric spaces

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: 1985; 155 p; ; University Microfilms Order No. 86-14,287; Thesis (Ph. D.).

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SYMMETRY; SYMMETRY BREAKING; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Non-Maximally symmetric spaces provide a more general background to explore the relation between the geometry of the manifold and the quantum fields defined in the manifold than those with maximally symmetric spaces. A static Taub universe is used to study the effect of curvature anisotropy on the spontaneous symmetry breaking of a self-interacting scalar field. The one-loop effective potential on a λphi4 field with arbitrary coupling xi is computed by zeta function regularization. For massless minimal coupled scalar fields, first order phase transitions can occur. Keeping the shape invariant but decreasing the curvature radius of the universe induces symmetry breaking. If the curvature radius is held constant, increasing deformation can restore the symmetry. Studies on the higher-dimensional Kaluza-Klein theories are also focused on the deformation effect. Using the dimensional regularization, the effective potential of the free scalar fields in M4 x T/sup N/ and M4 x (Taub)3 spaces are obtained. The stability criterions for the static solutions of the self-consistent Einstein equations are derived. Stable solutions of the M4 x S/sup N/ topology do not exist. With the Taub space as the internal space, the gauge coupling constants of SU(2), and U(1) can be determined geometrically. The weak angle is therefore predicted by geometry in this model

meta.content: January 1985

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The analogy between two-dimensional gravity and QED2 is discussed. It is shown that matter induces the Liouville equation in Einstein gravity and generates a mass in the four-derivative theory. The rules of bosonization in curved space are derived. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.content: COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; METRICS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; SPACE-TIME; WAVE PROPAGATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; RADIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The essence of General Relativity is general covariance. Every physical result must be coordinate independent. Still when performing an actual calculation a coordinate choice must be made. Clearly a good coordinate choice enables us to perform calculations that are impossible in other coordinates. This statement which is true all over physics is crucial in Numerical Relativity. Numerical Relativity emerged from the need to obtain solution of Enstein equations for strong field, dynamical highly non-symmetric configurations. The complexity and nonlinearity of Einstein equations leads us to numerical methods when we look for these solutions. The author focuses on the question of coordinates conditions and examines how they are implemented in current works in Numerical Relativity. (Auth.)

meta.content: January 1983
