meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Jensen, B.P.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: Texas Univ., Austin (USA)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Vacuum polarization on black hole space times

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: 1985; 81 p; ; University Microfilms Order No. 86-09,520; Thesis (Ph. D.).

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1530); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS; SPACE-TIME; VACUUM POLARIZATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The effects of vacuum polarization in black hole space times are examined. Particular attention is given to the vacuum physics inside the event horizon. The analytic properties of the solutions to the radial wave equation in Schwarzs child space time as functions of argument, frequency, and angular momentum are given. These functions are employed to define the Feynmann Green function (G/sub F/(x,x') for a scalar field subject to the Hartle-Hawking boundary conditions. An examination of the Schwarzschild mode functions near r = 0 is provided. This work is necessary background for a future calculation of <phi2> and the quantum stress-energy tensor for small r. Some opinions are given on how this calculation might be performed. A solution of the one-loop Einstein equations for Schwarzs child Anti-deSitter (SAdS) space time is presented, using Page's approximation to the quantum stress tensor. The resulting perturbed metric is shown to be unphysical, as it leads to a system of fields with infinite total energy. This problem is believed to be due to a failure of Page's method in SAdS. Suggestions are given on how one might correct the method

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1985

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SPACE; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The main steps in plotting the current gravitation theory and some prospects of its subsequent development are reviewed. The attention is concentrated on a comparison of the relativistic gravitational field with other physical fields. Two equivalent formulations of the general relativity (GR) - geometrical and field-theoretical - are considered in detail. It is shown that some theories of gravity constructed as the field theories at a flat background space-time are in fact just different formulations of GR and not alternative theories

assignment="upposted">tensors</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The main steps in plotting the current gravitation theory and some prospects of its subsequent development are reviewed. The attention is concentrated on a comparison of the relativistic gravitational field with other physical fields. Two equivalent formulations of the general relativity (GR) - geometrical and field-theoretical - are considered in detail. It is shown that some theories of gravity constructed as the field theories at a flat background space-time are in fact just different formulations of GR and not alternative theories</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="SU">USSR</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BOSON-EXCHANGE MODELS; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATRICES; PARTICLE MODELS; PERIPHERAL MODELS; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The author presents a formalism for generating string theories from two-dimensional nonlinear σ-models. Proceeding from an approach wherein the σ-mode is understood as a S-matrix generating functional of string amplitudes, the author develops both β-function-zero slope limit correspondence and a systematic slope expansion for the effective action. The author provides explicit perturbative calculations applicable to both open and closed strings which can be extended to include string loop effects. Alternatively, in some sense the nonlinear σ-model can be thought of as providing a nontrivial background in which the string evolves. The consistency of string dynamics, the requirement that the interacting quantum string maintains its classical conformal invariance, determines the background field configurations. This correspondence, in which equations associated with the β-functions for nonlinear σ-models provide the effective equations of motion for the massless fields, is developed. Thus he studies the renomalization up to two loops of bosonic and supersymmetric two-dimensional nonlinear σ-models with Wess-Zumino-Witten-like terms and calculate the β-functions of the metric and torsion potential. The generalized Einstein equation then follows

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: The conformal potential of the stationary axisymmetric vacuum

meta.name: Country

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: AXIAL SYMMETRY; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; KERR METRIC; POTENTIALS; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS; VACUUM STATES

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; METRICS; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In a stationary axisymmetric vacuum gravitational field, the conformal structure of the 3-space is determined by the symmetric, trace free and divergence-less tensor Y/sub ik/. Using the Killing vector K/sup i/ of the axisymmetry, the conformal potential U can be defined by U/sub ,i/ = epsilon/sub ijk/K/sup j/Y/sup kr/K/sub r/. Conversely, the tensor Y/sub ik/ is given algebraically in terms of the gradient U/sub ,i/ of the conformal potential. An attempt is made here to re-formulate the field equations R/sub lambdaμ/ = 0 in terms of the conformal potential. Introducing the Ernst potential as a complex coordinate, the cylindrical radius can be eliminated from the field equations. (author)

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Relativistic neutral superfluids. Exact solutions

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Nuovo Cim., B; v. 91(1) p. 31-56; ISSN 0369-3554; CODEN NCIBA; 11 Jan 1986

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; FLUIDS; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Relativistic superfluids are of great interest in astrophysics and cosmology. However, only a fraction of all the known exact, perfect-fluid solutions of Einstein equations also represents superfluids. Those found so far are given in this paper. They all correspond to neutral superfluids and are characterized, with a few exceptions, by equations of state P = αrho + const, with 0 < α <1 and rho proportional to the square of the number density. Some exact, superfluid solutions corresponding to inflationary universes are also given and classified

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MONOPOLES; POSTULATED PARTICLES; SPACE; SYMMETRY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Magnetostatic, axially symmetric 5-dimensional vacuum Einstein equations are formulated in terms of harmonic maps. A correspondence between stationary, axially symmetric 4-dimensional vacuum Einstein solutions and the magnetostatic, axially symmetric Jordan-Thiry solutions is established. The ''Kaluza-Klein magnetic monopole'' solution is recovered in a special case

meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Alonso, R.; Zamorano, N. (Departamento de Fisica, Facultad de Ciencias Fisicas y Matematicas, Universidad de Chile, Casilla 487/3, Santiago, Chile)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Generalized Kerr-Schild metric for a massless particle on the Reissner-Nordstroem horizon

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 35(6) p. 1798-1801; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Mar 1987

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; KERR METRIC; MASSLESS PARTICLES; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We show that the Dray and 't Hooft solution can be generated by a Kerr-Schild-type transformation starting with the Schwarzschild metric as a background metric. The power of this approach rests in the fact (proved by Taub) that the Einstein equations obtained by this method consist of a set of linear partial differential equations for the generating function. In this way it is possible to know the physical meaning (if any) of the solution found. We have extended the Dray and 't Hooft solution to the case with a Reissner-Nordstroem background metric

meta.content: January 1987

D, Particles Fields</title> <title type="abbreviated">Phys. Rev., D</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0556-2821</identifier> <identifier type="coden">PRVDA</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 35(6) p. 1798-1801.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1120" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="13598" assignment="indexer">kerr metric</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="13423" assignment="indexer">massless particles</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08872" assignment="indexer">schwarzschild metric</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03080" assignment="upposted">elementary particles</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="upposted">metrics</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">We show that the Dray and 't Hooft solution can be generated by a Kerr-Schild-type transformation starting with the Schwarzschild metric as a background metric. The power of this approach rests in the fact (proved by Taub) that the Einstein equations obtained by this method consist of a set of linear partial differential equations for the generating function. In this way it is possible to know the physical meaning (if any) of the solution found. We have extended the Dray and 't Hooft solution to the case with a Reissner-Nordstroem background metric</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: On relativistic electromagnetic gasodynamics

meta.name: Title
meta.content: K relyativistskoj ehlektromagnitnoj gazodinamike

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Zhurnal Ehksperimental'noj i Teoreticheskoj Fiziki; v. 91(4) p. 1144-1159; ISSN 0044-4510; CODEN ZETFA; Oct 1986; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics - JETP (USA).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CONSERVATION LAWS; CONTINUITY EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROGASDYNAMICS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MAGNETOGASDYNAMICS; MAXWELL EQUATIONS; PLASMA; RELATIVITY THEORY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; TENSORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: For the solution of a broad class of physical problems relating to systems containing large ensembles of particles interacting with strong gravitational and electromagnetic fields, the most suitable seems to be the mathematical apparatus of relativistic electromagnetic gasodynamics. The gasodynamic equations are usually derived from kinetics, specific problems being considered as a rule. In the present paper a deduction of a general equation set for relativistic electromagnetic gasodynamics within the limits of general and special relativity theories is presented. As in classical gasodynamics, the relativistic electrodynamic gasodynamics equations contain kinetic coefficients which are assumed to be known functions of the thermodynamic variables. Dissipative processes and processes related to the interaction of gases are described by the corresponding energy-momentum tensors. The lagrangian and hamiltonian forms for nondissipative relativistic gasodynamics are presented, and an equation set for symmetric stationary flows is derived

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1986

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BOSON-EXCHANGE MODELS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTEGRALS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE MODELS; PERIPHERAL MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SPACE

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: We review the progress which has recently been made in determining the spacetime backgrounds in which strings may consistently propagate. At the no-string-loop level, satisfactory backgrounds correspond to conformally invariant non-linear signal models and the condition of conformal invariance can be expressed as a field equation for the background spacetime. The problem of finding the effect of string loops on this picture is discussed. (orig.)

meta.content: January 1987

meta.content: Nonexistence of static conformally flat solutions in a new scalar--tensor theory

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; METRICS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: For the special case when the scalar field is massless and conformally invariant, it is shown that there do not exist spherically symmetric conformally flat solutions in a new scalar--tensor theory proposed by Schmidt et al. [Phys. Rev. D 24, 1484 (1981)] representing disordered radiation and in the presence of a source-free electromagnetic field except for the trivial empty flat space-time of Einstein's theory. The solution in the vacuum case is also only a flat space-time of Einstein's theory

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 1987

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Evolution of the very early universe with polarized vacuum

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: CLASSICAL MECHANICS; CORRECTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GALACTIC EVOLUTION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; QUANTUM MECHANICS; UNIVERSE; VACUUM POLARIZATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The Einstein equations with single-loop quantum corrections describing the vacuum polarization of physical fields are considered. It is shown that in the interval of times in which only the single-loop corrections are important for the strong classical gravitational field these equations give a unique stable solution of Friedmann type for the cosmological problem

meta.content: January 1985

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Inflationary stages in cosmological models with a scalar field

meta.name: Country
meta.content: United States

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Soviet Physics - JETP; v. 62(2) p. 195-203; ISSN 0038-5646; CODEN SPHJA; Aug 1985; Cover-to-cover translation of Zhurnal Ehksperimental'noj i Teoreticheskoj Fiziki (USSR).

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; SCALAR FIELDS; UNIVERSE

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The solutions of the gravitational equations for a homogeneous isotropic universe filled with a massive scalar field are investigated. Particular attention is paid to the question of the generality and conditions of realization of inflationary stages of expansion. It is shown that inflationary stages are an unavoidable property of a large class of solutions. The results of the paper indicate that the concept of spontaneous creation of the universe with a subsequent inflationary stage probably does not require the fulfillment of any too special requirements

meta.content: January 1985

D. Landau Institute of Theoretical Physics, USSR Academy of Sciences</creator> </creators> <availability inis="no"> <contact>Bibliographic information available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:18081579</contact> </availability> <notes> <note>Cover-to-cover translation of Zhurnal Ehksperimental'noj i Teoreticheskoj Fiziki (USSR).</note> </notes> <is-part-of> <journal> <titles> <title type="primary">Soviet Physics - JETP</title> <title type="abbreviated">Sov. Phys. - JETP (Engl. Transl.)</title> </titles> <identifiers> <identifier type="issn">0038-5646</identifier> <identifier type="coden">SPHJA</identifier> </identifiers> <physical-description>v. 62(2) p. 195-203.</physical-description> </journal> </is-part-of> </publication> <classification> <categories> <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1550" /> </categories> <descriptors> <descriptor type="valid" key="02277" assignment="indexer">cosmological models</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="08816" assignment="indexer">scalar fields</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="10631" assignment="indexer">universe</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor> <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor> </descriptors> <abstracts> <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The solutions of the gravitational equations for a homogeneous isotropic universe filled with a massive scalar field are investigated. Particular attention is paid to the question of the generality and conditions of realization of inflationary stages of expansion. It is shown that inflationary stages are an unavoidable property of a large class of solutions. The results of the paper indicate that the concept of spontaneous creation of the universe with a subsequent inflationary stage probably does not require the fulfillment of any too special requirements</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.name: Authors
meta.content: Husain, V.

meta.name: CorporateAuthors
meta.content: International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Ashtekar variables, self-dual metrics, and w∞

meta.name: Country
meta.content: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2110)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HAMILTONIANS; METRICS; QUANTIZATION; SYMMETRY

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; QUANTUM OPERATORS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: The self-duality equations for for the Riemann tensor are studied using the Ashtekar Hamiltonian formulation for general relativity. These equations may be written as dynamical equations for three divergence free vector fields on a three dimensional surface in the spacetime. An ansatz is used to explicitly solve these equations for self-dual metrics with a one Killing field symmetry. The ansatz is such that, in an appropriate coordinate system, the self-duality conditions reduce to a condition for canonical coordinates on a two dimensional surface. The resulting metrics are parametrized by an arbitrary function of two variables. As a result of this parametrization, there is an infinite dimensional symmetry algebra acting on this subset of the solution space. This is the algebra of area preserving diffeomorphisms, a particular case of which is called w∞. As an example of the procedure, a complex self-dual metric on the 4-torus (a 'non-linear graviton') is given. (author). 15 refs

meta.content: January 1992

meta.name: English-Title
meta.content: Quasinormal modes of the scalar field in five-dimensional Lovelock black hole spacetime

meta.name: Source
meta.content: Chinese Physics. B; v. 19(6); ISSN 1674-1056; Jun 2010; [6 p.]; ; Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1674-1056/19/6/060401; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

meta.name: RecordType
meta.content: Journal article

meta.name: SubjectCategory
meta.content: ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

meta.name: DEI
meta.content: BLACK HOLES; CORRECTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; ULTRAVIOLET RADIATION; WKB APPROXIMATION

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: APPROXIMATIONS; CALCULATION METHODS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; RADIATIONS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: In this paper, using the third-order WKB approximation, we investigate the quasinormal frequencies of the scalar field in the background of a five-dimensional Lovelock black hole. We find that the ultraviolet correction to Einstein theory in the Lovelock theory makes the scalar field decay more slowly and oscillate more quickly, and the cosmological constant makes the scalar field decay more slowly and oscillate more slowly in the Lovelock black hole background. (general)

meta.content: January 2010

meta.name: DEC
meta.content: BOSONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GRAND UNIFIED THEORY; LEPTONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATTER; PARTICLE MODELS; PHYSICS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RELATIVITY THEORY; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: Full text: The accelerating expansion of the Universe points to a small positive vacuum energy density and negative vacuum pressure. A strong candidate is the cosmological constant in Einstein's equations of General Relativity. The vacuum dark energy density extracted from astrophysics is 1056 times smaller than the value expected from the Higgs potential in Standard Model particle physics and 1044 times smaller than the contribution expected from QCD condensates. The dark energy scale is however close to the range of possible values expected for the light neutrino mass. We discuss the cosmological constant puzzle and (new) ideas how to solve it. (author)

xml:lang="en">Full text: The accelerating expansion of the Universe points to a small positive vacuum energy density and negative vacuum pressure. A strong candidate is the cosmological constant in Einstein's equations of General Relativity. The vacuum dark energy density extracted from astrophysics is 1056 times smaller than the value expected from the Higgs potential in Standard Model particle physics and 1044 times smaller than the contribution expected from QCD condensates. The dark energy scale is however close to the range of possible values expected for the light neutrino mass. We discuss the cosmological constant puzzle and (new) ideas how to solve it. (author)</abstract> </abstracts> </classification> <administratives> <input-center type="subj" key="AT">Austria</input-center> <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights> </administratives> </record> </inisrecord></body></html>

meta.content: CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; PHYSICS

meta.name: Abstract
meta.content: For an arbitrarily strong, spherically symmetric super-horizon curvature perturbation, we present analytic solutions of the Einstein equations in terms of the asymptotic expansion over the ratio of the Hubble radius to the length-scale of the curvature perturbation to set initial conditions for numerical computations of primordial black hole formation. To obtain this solution we develop a recursive method of quasi-linearization which reduces the problem to a system of coupled ordinary differential equations for the Nth order terms in the asymptotic expansion with sources consisting of a non-linear combination of the lower order terms

meta.name: PublicationYear
meta.content: January 2012
